They all return to the One. Taking this as measure is called "immeasurable."

A verse says:
Gazing from on high, how many leagues are seen?
Boundless and infinite, profoundly obscure.
Looking up and down, the vastness of Heaven and Earth unknown—
One must embrace and unify the true.

Salvation: The Dao has no form, yet by containing light, it establishes humanity;
It has no root, yet transforms the false into the true.
The Original One transforms to generate spirit,
Spirit transforms to generate the true,
The true transforms to generate the Dao."

Things borrow things to complete things; humans borrow the true to complete the Dao.
Recognizing things while guarding the true—this is called "salvation."

A verse says:
The earthen and wooden form is ultimately empty,
Within the shadow of ignorance, chasing the vast chaos.
One must rely on extraordinary arts beyond things,
Only then can one soar free from the cage of the world.

The human is the subtle inquiry into the profound and indistinct;
the human exists within it.
Vague and indistinct, spirit is born in fire;
profound and obscure, essence is born in water.
Fire flames upward, seven transformations make spirit;
water flows downward, six transformations make essence.
The seven and six transformations, above and below completing each other,
spirit and essence intermingling, the wondrous body contains the true.
Each true to its truth—this is called the "true person."

A verse says:
This body is originally of incomparable worth,
Originally serene and still, connecting heaven and earth.
Creation relies solely on yin and yang,
Earth, water, fire, and wind are all impurities.

The highest is the Dao’s subtlety.
Swallowing the red, absorbing the yellow, inhaling the blue-green, ingesting the white,
gathering the primordial in the primordial palace, giving birth to spirit and form.
Then, abandoning the ten thousand things, forsaking the ten thousand transformations,
alone attaining the mysterious—this is called "the highest of the high."

A verse says:
Three hundred merits achieved, ten thousand practices wondrous,
Amid the dust, seizing the prize and returning.
The Jade Terrace has already inscribed your name,
Only then does a man’s ambition show no baseness.

Rank: recognizing the many while observing the One,
guarding the One and embracing the One,
returning to our utmost One—this is called "rank."
The Dao is originally formless; how could words have rank?
For expedient teaching, ranks are thus established.

A verse says:
Three thousand six hundred dharma gates are many,
One must clearly recognize the correct one.
The great Dao does not expect a thousand days to complete;
do not let the years and months pass in vain.

The wondrous is the origin of the ten thousand methods.
Thus, heaven and earth are empty and wondrous yet clear;
yin and yang share the wondrous and are pure;
the sun and moon unite in the wondrous and are bright;
the five phases contain the wondrous and are refined;
the ten thousand things are all wondrous and true.
The wondrous gaze sees the formless form;
the wondrous hearing hears the soundless sound.
Not to be seen, not to be heard, not to be had, not to be without—
this is called true wondrousness.

A verse says:
Neither non-being nor being, originally pure and true,
Neither form nor sound, beyond all comparison.
Where depiction and description cannot reach,
In the profound, the position and image are most distinct.

The scripture is the warp and weft of heaven and earth;
the sun and moon move, day and night unceasing,
endlessly cycling, transforming without exhaustion.
The ancients, looking up and down, necessarily relied on the Dao,
not transgressing the path, not losing constancy,
not losing their essence through external things—
this is the root of the scripture.

A verse says:
Counting on fingers, the master’s compassionate vow,
The black pearl is not idly cast aside.
Clearly pointing to the immortal’s path for me,
Repay the profound grace of the mountains and peaks without fail.

**Eulogy for "Original Beginning"**
Before the great image, forcibly named "Original,"
Ancestor of heaven and earth, source of the ten thousand things.
After the Three Powers divided, a beginning could be spoken;
humans know to return, ultimately reverting to their root.
True emptiness, luminous illumination, before kalpas.

**Eulogy for "Boundless"**
Before form existed, the Dao was truly here,
Its name unknown, thus called "without";
Unfathomable, who could probe or perceive?
Taking this as measure, its measure cannot be reckoned;
Mysterious and again mysterious, those who awaken return together.

**Eulogy for "Salvation of Humans"**
Once form exists, transformation begins here;
What causes transformation, if not the Dao?
Transforming the false into true, decay into wonder.
Among the multitude, why be uniquely different?
Shedding the mortal to enter the sacred, merging with the subtle and rare.

**Eulogy for "Supreme Rank"**
Its height unknown, thus called "supreme";
A thing formed in chaos, before heaven and earth.
Looking up from below, who stands before it?
Taking this as rank, how could words suffice to declare!
Among all peers, uniquely transcendent and surpassing.

**Eulogy for "Wondrous Scripture"**
The morning sun rises in the east, the night moon hangs in the sky,
Jade emerges from uncut stone, pearls appear in oyster shells.
The most precious is the Dao; how could the wondrous be exhausted?
Spreading forth as scripture, eternally constant and unchanging,
Heaven and earth have kalpas, the wondrous scripture has no end.

**Chapter on the Original Beginning Expounding the Dao and Universally Salvation**
Expounding the Dao and virtue, enlightening humans and heavens,
Governing the three realms—this is called "universal."
*Collation:* The scripture contains Daoist words; these two chapters serve as their banner,
and the *Qingyuan Zhenren Scripture Commentary* uses this to represent one of the two chapters.

Establishing images to initiate cultivation, four hundred fifty-seven words.
Ordinary beings, their nature obscured, turn from their root and lose the true,
thus first establishing image-methods to open the path,
as the root of the Dao.
*Collation:* The *Preface to the Qingyuan Scripture Commentary* by the Old Man of Qinghe says:
"Divided into eight matters"—this is one of those eight.

The Original Beginning, cavernously mysterious,
the root chapter of the Numinous Treasure,
supreme wondrous head,
ten cycles of salvation,
hundred demons hidden in rhyme,
naturally converging and diverging.
This is the original intent of the *Scripture of the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign*,
speaking of the Heavenly Worthy containing the vast and wondrous Dao,
endowed with spontaneity,
covering the ten thousand ranks,
most honored and most noble,
penetratingly observing the mysterious One,
transforming and saving humans and heavens—
thus called the *Cavernously Mysterious Original Beginning*.
With great wisdom and luminous brilliance, it illuminates the ten directions of the world.
In heaven, it is called "numinous"; in the world, it is called "treasure"—
thus called *Numinous Treasure*.
All spoken from the golden mouth, thus called the "root chapter,"
fully containing the root of cultivating the true and uniting with the Dao.
Its rank is supreme, the head of all wonders,
secretly concealing the taboo names of demonic truths.
Converging with primordial qi to congeal,
dispersing as qi, converging as script,
this is the Dao of transformation and fluctuation,
not to be compared to ink traces,
the ancestor of the ten thousand methods,
the honored one of the Three Caverns.
The wise recognize it and cultivate to complete the treasure.
The *Yellow Court Scripture* says:
"The Dao of nurturing life is not troublesome;
ancestral cultivation is the *Cavernous Mystery* and the *Jade Chapters*."

This is what is meant.

The ode says:
To know the Primordial Beginning’s method of delivering beings,
the *Numinous Treasure* was originally called the "root chapter."
Within it lie the hundred demons—who can comprehend?
If one can part and merge, radiance arises naturally.

The *Crimson Writ of Primal Chaos*, the Supreme Truth of Non-Being,
the Primordial Beginning of the Ancestral Kalpa,
transforms and gives birth to all heavens.
Illuminating the Three Luminaries,
this is the root of heaven,
above which there is no further ancestor—
only the Dao as its body.
The Five Scripts unfold and expand,
universally planting the divine spirits.

*Primal Chaos* is the state before heaven and earth divided.
Before the Primordial Beginning,
its qi was pure and crimson,
wind and marsh intermingling—
this is the *Great Cavern*.
When script first took form,
only the Heavenly Worthy stood solitary in serene independence,
abiding in the supreme of Non-Being,
attaining the utmost truth within truth—
thus called the *Supreme Truth of Non-Being*.
The *Primordial Beginning of the Ancestral Kalpa*
is the lesser kalpa of *Dragon Han*, called *Yan Kang*.
First, one qi gave birth to three qi,
forming the Three Pure Realms above;
the three qi gave birth to nine qi,
completing the Nine Heavens.
Beyond the Nine Heavens lie the Thirty-Two Heavens—
thus are all heavens transformed and born.
Then the sun, moon, and stars were arrayed,
governing the ten thousand things—
this is the illumination of the Three Luminaries,
the image of heaven and earth,
yet it does not escape the workings of change and transformation.

The Heavenly Worthy, containing the beginning of *Primal Chaos*,
generated the true qi of the Five Phases,
condensing them into talismanic scripts
to pacify and stabilize heaven and earth,
giving birth to and transforming divine spirits,
abiding in the Three Realms
to govern the ten thousand methods.
Thus, they hang without falling,
enduring without decay.
From these Five Scripts were unfolded the five thousand characters,
fully containing the root of the wondrous, primordial, divine, and true Dao,
corresponding above to the Five Phases—
the origin of all transformation.

Like a person before form,
where does the spirit reside?
Chaotic and undifferentiated,
dense and obscure,
without division or distinction,
neither existent nor non-existent—
Non-Being is called the Dao,
the Dao is the root of humanity.
When this Dao scatters,
it becomes simplicity.
Simplicity scatters into qi,
qi congeals to form spirit,
and when spirit is complete,
form arises.
This is the original source of humanity,
its primordial beginning.

Then the Three Fields are arrayed,
the Nine Orifices opened,
the Five Viscera and Six Bowels formed—
the image of all heavens transformed and born.
The *Three Fields* are the convergence of essence and blood,
the root and origin of the ten thousand qi.
This is the illumination of the Three Luminaries,
the foundation of yin and yang in the body,
the root of nourishment and defense.

Though a person’s life begins in the womb,
its origin arises from the beginning of the Primordial Beginning.
Who is ancestor? Who is lineage?
Receiving the Dao’s qi as substance,
borrowing essence and blood as form,
dwelling within to accomplish transformation—
this is how it is.
When the Five Spirits are arrayed,
then the thirty-six thousand joints
simultaneously generate spirit from their root and origin.
Is this not the universal planting of divine spirits?

Thus, the Dao is not far from humanity.
If one awakens and cultivates,
one may ascend as an immortal.
The foolish, clinging to delusion,
fail to honor their qi,
value their root,
preserve their life,
or secure their form—
they bring about their own decay and death,
severing their original truth.
Thus, they distance themselves from the Dao.

The ode says:

The supreme truth stands beyond the formless,
originating in the Dragon Han, enduring to this day.
Neither increasing nor diminishing, ever pure and still—
this is called the Great Dharmakāya.

Without script, no radiance;
without script, no illumination;
without script, no establishment;
without script, no completion;
without script, no deliverance;
without script, no generation.

When the Great Simplicity scattered, Heaven and Earth divided;
when the numinous script coalesced, the Jade Characters emerged.
Thereafter, the myriad forms gained light,
the myriad forms unfolded in clarity,
the myriad dharmas were firmly established,
the myriad things self-completed,
the myriad spirits received deliverance,
and the myriad kinds were born.
Had the primordial qi not divided and the Five Scripts not taken form,
how could generation and completion have come to be?

As with human birth—
were it not for the Dao’s qi descending to nourish with true numen,
opening and transforming,
how could this illusory, colored body stand firm?

The ode says:
The Numinous Treasure’s light first revealed,
its splendor resplendent, timeless and bright.
It stabilizes Heaven, anchors Earth, manifests creation—
not mere words upon paper.

This is the Great Brahmā,
the Heaven within Heaven,
the Yu Luo Xiao Terrace,
the Jade Mountain’s Upper Capital.
Supreme beyond the supreme,
the Great Net of Jade Purity,
boundless and measureless,
now present, now absent—
the Three Flowers depart, the wondrous court of Great Existence,
golden palaces and jade chambers,
a forest of purity and clarity.

The Great Brahmā qi circulates through the ten directions.
Within it dwell the immortal-delivering spirits,
the Southern Culmen’s Lord of Longevity,
the world-delivering Marshal of the Controller of Horses,
the life-cherishing Lord Han the Venerable,
the Southern Supernal Lords of Destiny and Records,
who extend life and augment fate,
the revered spirits who deliver from calamity,
who restore bones and raise the dead—
boundless deliverance of beings.

Today, as the register is reviewed,
the myriad heavens descend to the imperial terrace.

From the formless and beyond, all are called Brahmā Heavens.
This "Great Brahmā" refers to the first coagulation of the Dao’s qi.
The "Heaven within Heaven" is the sacred realm of the Three Purities and Great Net.
"Great" means covering the myriad heavens;
"Net" means encompassing the Three Realms.
Supreme beyond the supreme, thus it is called the Great Net.
Within it stands the Jade Capital Mountain,
eighty thousand leagues in circumference,
opposite Kunlun below.
The mountain bears the Yu Luo Xiao Terrace,
the terrace holds a seven-jeweled city,
the city contains the Jade Purity Hall,
where the Heavenly Worthy resides.

"Supreme" refers to the boundless.
Vast and unfathomable,
only the highest immortals perceive it;
middle and lower immortals cannot glimpse it.
Its height spans immeasurable leagues,
now appearing, now vanishing—
thus it is said to be now present, now absent,
the ebb and flow of the Primordial Beginning.

There is also the Palace of the Three Flowers Departed,
the court of Great Existence—
both places of repose.
When the Heavenly Emperors of the myriad heavens convene,
they must circumambulate thrice while chanting void-steps,
only then do they behold the Jade Countenance.

Golden palaces and jade chambers,
jade pools and emerald waters,
stand in solemn array.
Sustained by the ceaseless circulation of Brahmā qi,
they endure eternally.

Within this palace dwells the immortal-delivering spirit,
a manifestation of the Primordial Beginning.
The Lord of Longevity is the Great Emperor of Vermilion Mound,
who governs the Supreme Subtlety Enclosure,
overseeing the alchemy of fire.
The world-delivering Lord presides over the cycles of ninety-six solar phases.
The Marshal of the Controller of Horses dispels evil and averts trials.
The life-cherishing Lord is another name for Azure Radiance,
who oversees the evaluation of merits.
Lord Han governs Nanchang,
ranking and assessing practitioners.

The Lords of Destiny and Records govern merit and transgression,
bestowing or withholding, extending life and augmenting fate.
The spirits of deliverance from calamity resolve and pacify hardships.
The Lord of Restoring Bones and Raising the Dead ascends and delivers the dead,
causing flying corpses to ascend at dawn.

When the Heavenly Worthy expounds the Dao,
all are summoned to attend the imperial terrace,
reviewing registers and examining records,
ranking and delivering practitioners.

The human body, precious as the seven jewels,
is no different from the Jade Capital.
The brain palace is the Yu Luo Terrace,
golden palaces and jade chambers,
a forest of purity and clarity,
arrayed in profound stillness.
The immortal-delivering spirit resides within.
If the Brahmā qi circulates without cease,
it is like Heaven’s unceasing revolution—
enduring without decay.

The ode says:
Brahmā qi circulates through the ten directions,
the Jade Capital and golden palaces radiant in splendor.
With dispassionate inward contemplation,
the Three Purity realms are all the land of long life and immortality.

The collation states:
The scripture speaks of the transformation of the myriad heavens,
and of the "Great Brahmā Heaven within Heaven,"
extending to the Great Net of Jade Purity.
The commentary has already clarified this in a separate record.

It also lists the Nine Heavens, Nine Empyreans,
and the names of the Brahmā qi heavens and empyreans,
which are appended here:

First Green Heaven, paired with Grand Empyrean’s Radiant Flowing Light and Plain Effulgence Heaven;
Azure Origin Heaven, paired with Azure Empyrean’s Primordial True Treasure Radiance Heaven;
First Vermilion Heaven, paired with Vermilion Empyrean’s General Life-Opening Numinous Transmission Heaven;
Grand Vermilion Heaven, paired with Crimson Empyrean’s Great Peace Response and Transformation Dao Lord Heaven;
First Plain Heaven, paired with Scenic Empyrean’s Central Culmen’s Supreme Wondrous Transformation Void Heaven;

Beginning from the east and extending through the ten directions, the Dao qi divides its forms, its wonders unfathomable. These are the honorific titles of the Flying Heavenly Great Sage, Limitless Divine Kings. The Divine Kings succeed the Primordial Beginning and are born; since before the Dragon Han kalpa, when the Primordial Beginning first spread transformation, these deities were first established to grasp and uphold the heavenly qi, to oversee and encompass the heavenly immortals, to govern life and death, to thoroughly regulate the tally of yin, and to protect the myriad people. Whenever a kalpic cycle ends, the Divine Kings mold and refine the cultivators, conducting the work of recommending and promoting them; all standards for ascent and descent are entirely under their charge.

The ode says:
The Dharmakāya is originally without distinct form,
Yet manifests in the ten directions, fundamentally the same.
Only because the Great Sage can attain longevity,
Does the deliverance of beings become boundlessly immeasurable.

The perfected of the ten directions, the Flying Heavenly Divine Kings, the Longevity Deliverers of the World, Immeasurable Great Spirits, all ride upon flying clouds, cinnabar chariots and green palanquins, feathered canopies and jade wheels, drawn by crimson phoenixes and five-colored dark dragons, bearing nine-colored standards and ten mystic pennants. Ahead, nine phoenixes cry in unison; behind, eight luan-birds sing in harmony. Lions and white cranes chant and sing in concord, while the Five Elders clear the path and the host of immortals flank the procession. With a hundred thousand chariots and ten thousand riders, they arrive through the void, turning their radiant carriages to oversee the deliverance of the true and the salvation of the living. The chariots, wheels, and canopies are all formed from the qi of yang essence; the phoenixes, dragons, and cranes are transformations of the qi of yin essence. The supremely sagely, possessing the Dao of true constancy, can gather and disperse their breath at will, manifesting as they please. The harmonious qi of yin and yang forms songs and melodies, all the work of pure truth, not of external things. If one can cultivate and refine the numinous treasure within, banishing all yin demons and assembling the yang spirit, one will meet at the palace of refined truth. With a single exhalation of primordial qi, the myriad spirits all heed; the spirits of the five viscera each manifest in their directional colors, and chariots, palanquins, and attendants come to welcome. Then the hundred bones and host of spirits, leading and following, ascend to pay homage to the origin—no different from this.

The ode says:
The splendid and profuse divine retinue is of unmatched nobility,
Yet the blended reed-pipe songs all form no discord.
Who brings about this scene of splendor?
In truth, it is none other than one’s own self.

One hundred fifty-eight words on delivering from life and death. Earlier, symbols were established to encourage the cultivation of truth; now, the salvation of the living and deliverance from death shall be carried out to manifest the work of universal deliverance.

Collated and noted: This is the second of eight sections in the Azure Primordial’s annotated sutra.

The chancellors of the various heavens, the Divine Overseer of the Southern Prosperity Upper Palace, the Han Controller of Records, and the Great Spirit Who Supervises Birth, holding registers and ledgers, all assemble before the Emperor. According to those who ought to be delivered, they strictly examine the various heavens. Each of the Thirty-Two Heavens has its own chancellor, who assists the celestial sovereign and serves as the office that records and maintains the ledgers. The Southern Prosperity is the Cinnabar Heaven realm and the Vermilion Numinous Fire Mansion, the place where cultivators are transformed and refined after their transition. The Han Controller is the scribe within the palace, responsible for the records of refinement and deliverance. The Supervisor of Birth is another name for the one who forges the hun-soul and po-soul, overseeing rebirth. Moved by the vow-power of the Heavenly Worthy, each holds their registers and ledgers, assembling before the Emperor to examine those who ought to receive deliverance: some by their innate names in the mysterious charts, their bone configurations matching those of immortals; some by their cultivation of fasts and observance of precepts, their accumulated merit and virtue moving the heavens; some by their reverence for the Three Treasures, their good works penetrating the heavens; or by their offerings to the Teacher-Treasure, recorded by the Three Officials. Those whose names are proclaimed in the various heavens are each strictly examined and assessed, then promoted and delivered according to the measure of their merit.

The ode says:
The summoning of the various heavens to assemble in the imperial court—
For what reason are these meticulous examinations and records made?
Those in the world who accumulate goodness and amass great merit
Will have the refining and deliverance of the Southern Prosperity.

A universal announcement to the Three Realms, the Limitless Divine Regions, the Yellow Springs and Crooked Springs Mansion, the Northern Capital of Fengdu, the Three Offices and Nine Bureaus, and the Twelve River Sources: may the karmic debts of ancestors and parents from a hundred kalpas be absolved, their ledgers of transgressions expunged, their evil roots eradicated. They must not be detained or coerced into joining the ghostly multitudes; by the talismanic command of the Primordial Beginning, they shall be promoted and transferred at the appointed hour.

The Three Realms are Heaven, Earth, and Water. The Limitless Divine Regions encompass all the divine courts and shrines within the Three Realms. The Yellow Springs and Crooked Springs lie at the lowest depths of the northern abyss, serving as the key repository for the rivers and seas, where the ledgers of sinful souls are stored. The Northern Capital of Fengdu: beyond the heavens formed by the ascending pure qi, the congealing of turbid qi gives rise to this mountain, located in the north of the cosmos. The mountain stands five hundred fifty-five thousand five hundred li high, with a circumference of thirty thousand li. Its summit reaches the azure vault, and its base touches the wind and springs; the black and murky qi coils about it. Within the mountain are the six celestial cavern-palaces: first, the Palace of the Yin of Utter Destruction; second, the Palace of the Sect of Truthful Punishment; third, the Palace of the City of Martial Endurance; fourth, the Palace of the Qi of Sinful Calm; fifth, the Palace of the Seven Transgressions of the Ancestral Numen; sixth, the Palace of the Daring Controller of the Winding Abyss. Each palace is governed by a great demon king, who serves as the overarching authority of the Three Primes and the central office of the Five Marchmounts.

Moreover, there are three palaces:

The Upper Prime Palace rests upon the mountain’s flank, nearest to Heaven. The Celestial Bureau oversees it, charged with reviewing merits, recording good deeds, and promoting or demoting ranks.

The Middle Prime Palace lies to the mountain’s left, governed by the Terrestrial Bureau. Within it stands the Spirit Prison, where guilty souls are judged and summoned to account.

The Lower Prime Palace stands to the mountain’s right, close to the Wind Ramparts, under the jurisdiction of the Aquatic Bureau. Beneath it stretch the Nine Great Prisons of the Frigid Waters, the Courts of the Eight Tribulations, where the world’s most heinous and rebellious sinners are confined.

Each of these three palaces contains three bureaus, and each bureau comprises one hundred twenty nether-offices. All officials within the bounds of Mount Fengdu number ninety-nine million nine hundred ninety-nine thousand, all chosen from among the world’s most enlightened spirits.

The Nine Departments are the Nine Ramparts of the Earth Sovereigns and the Nine Command Offices. The Twelve River Sources—such as the guiding of Mount Qian and Mount Bo—serve as the places where guilty souls are divided and judged.

Now the Heavenly Venerable has commanded all heavens to strictly examine and promote the adepts. He has also issued the Nine Dragon Talismanic Decrees, universally proclaiming to the Three Primes, ordering that for the adepts, the sins of their ancestors and collateral kin from kalpas past be swiftly expunged from the registers, the roots of the Three Evil Realms eradicated, and no lingering obstructions allowed to bind them to the ranks of imprisoned ghosts. Thus, they shall be promoted at once.

A hymn says:
Who proclaims the talismanic decree?
It releases the dark prisons’ suffering bonds.
Returning to the root, restoring the origin, it revives destiny—
Each person, at every moment, ascends.

The Northern Capital’s Frigid Pool marshals and guards the forms and souls, restrains demons, ensures protection and promotion, and ranks them for the Southern Palace. The dead souls undergo refinement; through immortal transformation, they become human. Those who receive the living-body liberation endure kalpa after kalpa, everlasting. As kalpas turn, they share Heaven’s years.

Within the yin realm of Mount Fengdu lies the Capital of Solitary Darkness and Utter Desolation, governed by the Five Numinous Elders of the Five Qi Heavenly Lords. Amid the Nine Earths, the Northern Yin Heavenly Lord presides; amid the Nine Waters, the Great Abyssal Water Emperor rules. Together, they are called the Northern Capital. There dwell the Three Realms’ Great Demons, the Three-Five Generals, the Six Jia Officials, the Five Thearchs’ Examiners, as well as the Punitive Divine Soldiers and the Ten Thousand Mighty Heavenly Warriors—all deities who oversee the registers of guilty souls.

Those in the world who cultivate shallowly yet bear deep karmic burdens cannot avoid returning here. In life, they are yang souls; in death, they become yin spirits. If their deluded roots remain unsevered, their yin souls scatter and dissolve, impossible to grasp. Thus, their forms are marshaled and guarded to prevent dissolution, demons are restrained, and protection and promotion are ensured. They are ranked in the Southern Palace, where the dead souls undergo the Great Fire’s refinement. Their ghostly substance is consumed entirely, and then they are feather-transformed into immortals.

The “dead souls undergoing refinement” refers to the rebirth of flesh and blood—not merely the body born of parents, but the Dao-body. Thus, it is called the “living body.” Once this Dao-body receives immortal liberation, it turns with the kalpas and shares Heaven’s years.

A hymn says:
The form and soul need only my support;
Restrain the demons, and they will not deceive.
This living body must liberate itself—
To wait for their protection would be too late.

Eternally liberating from the Three Paths, the Five Sufferings, and the Eight Tribulations, transcending the Three Realms, and roaming freely in the Highest Clarity.

The Heaven of Highest Clarity is the Jade Thearch’s realm, the colorless realm of Brahman conduct. The Three Paths refer to hell, the ghost realm, and the animal realm. The Five Sufferings include the knife mountains and sword trees, as well as the worldly sufferings of birth, aging, poverty, sickness, and death. The Eight Tribulations refer to falling into alien forms, being born lowly, having misshapen features, living in borderlands, possessing violent natures, not encountering a benevolent ruler, constantly facing war and fire, and all manner of karmic obstructions arising from good deeds.

Thus, the *Scripture of the Three Paths and Five Sufferings* states: “When the three karmas are pure, one does not fall into the Three Paths.” These are the body, mind, and speech. From these three karmas arise the ten evils’ roots, the source of all karma. When karma is pure, hell ceases to exist; when speech is pure, ghostly qi dissipates; when the body is pure, one is not reborn in alien realms. Abandoning the five poisons eliminates the Five Sufferings. The five poisons are the eye beholding the five colors, the nose smelling the five fragrances, the tongue savoring the five flavors, the ear hearing the five sounds, and the mind generating the five desires. If even one sense and one dust are purified, from where could the Five Sufferings and evil paths arise? They would naturally vanish.

Cultivating the Eight Practices dissolves the Eight Tribulations. These are benevolence, filial piety, loyalty, trustworthiness, integrity, gentleness, forbearance, precept-keeping, and equanimity. From these Eight Practices arise the roots of all virtues and the foundation for transcending the world. Some interpret the Eight Tribulations as the affairs of imprisonment in hell, but this is a limited view, not encompassing the ultimate principle. The correct understanding lies here.

The Highest Clarity is the Jade Thearch’s capital, the colorless realm of the Great Dao. Brahman conduct refers to the Dharma—there are methods to cultivate and practices to advance, hence it is called Brahman conduct. When dead souls receive liberation, they pay homage to the Imperial Capital, then ascend to their respective heavens according to merit, progressing step by step in cultivation.

A hymn says:
All defilements arise from the mind’s dimness;
The Three Paths and Five Sufferings burden the form and soul.
When the Heavenly Light washes away the roots and dusts,
Immortal transformation faces the origin and pays homage to the Supreme.

This section describes the ranks of the four hundred thirteen heavens.

Previously, the decree was issued to the Three Realms to root out life and death and promote the adepts. Next, the ranks of ascent and descent among the various heavens shall be expounded, to demonstrate the stages of progress in cultivation.

A note on collation: This is the third of eight sections in the *Blue Prime’s Annotated Scripture*.

The Eastern Eight Heavens: The Primordial Beginning accumulated the nine yang Brahman qi to form them. Thus, they correspond to the Eastern Six Heavens, comprising the two heavens of the Desire Realm and the Yellow Top Heaven of the Form Realm, which stands at the head of the Void Brahman’s constellations, next to Kui and Bi. The remaining seven heavens’ constellations follow: Dipper, Ox, Girl, Void, Rooftop, House, and Wall.

A note on collation: Another edition annotates the imperial vestments, with the six heavens of the Desire Realm being the Azure Crown, Azure Robe, Azure Garment, and Azure Skirts. ○ The nine yang are divided into pure and turbid; the qi of singular lightness forms the heavens, which lie beneath the host of heavens, fifty-two billion myriad leagues from the mortal realm, at the boundary of the Wind Firmament. Those who practice the Threefold Purity and establish the merit of a hundred virtues are reborn in these heavens. The lifespans of the heavenly beings vary; newly ascended from the mortal realm, their defilements of desire are not yet extinguished, and thus the inhabitants of these heavens possess visible forms. Among them, some regard clasping hands as desire, others words or glances, still others bodily union—hence the name Desire Realm. The bliss of these heavens surpasses all others, and thus many cling to it greedily; signs of decline readily appear, and when their lifespans end, they sink once more into the various destinies. If they gradually cultivate and suddenly extinguish the defilements of desire, they ascend into the Form Realm. Practicing the Lesser Vehicle’s Way may realize this state, known as heavenly beings. As the sutras say: those who cultivate the Six Perfections and walk the path of initial progress. These heavens possess the Three Hundred Sixty Precepts of Grand Purity to restrain their inhabitants. When the great kalpa’s fire arises from the roots of Kunlun, the world is scorched by Brahman flames, and the conflagration ascends to the Harmony Yang Heaven; there, the primordial qi dissolves, and the heavens collapse.

A hymn says:
Jade towers and pearl pavilions are the roots of desire,
Fair maidens and radiant beauties play celestial melodies.

Should one but cease to indulge in attachments,
The halo behind the nape grows ever brighter.

The Eighteen Heavens constitute the Form Realm.
Here, the clear and turbid qi, refined into subtle clarity,
Form their hues, distinct from the formless below.
Thirty myriad leagues above the Desire Realm,
Amidst the cinnabar mists’ splendor,
Those of the Six Dust Heavens who observe the Three Hundred Precepts of the Lower Primordial,
Accumulating three hundred virtues’ merit,
Ascend to these heavens.
Those of the Fine Dust Heavens who observe the Five Hundred Precepts of the Middle Primordial,
Accumulating seven hundred virtues’ merit,
Ascend to these heavens.
Those of the Light Dust Heavens who observe the Seven Hundred Precepts of the Upper Primordial,
Accumulating eight hundred virtues’ merit,
Ascend to these heavens.
Though free from passionate desire,
They still possess visible forms and hues—
Hence, the Form Realm.
Should one gradually cultivate and suddenly extinguish the dust-like defilements,
So that form and hue no longer arise,
One enters the Formless Realm.
If attachment arises, one may yet fall back to the lower heavens.
Practicing the Middle Vehicle’s Way may realize this state,
Known as Heavenly Immortals.
The loftiest among them are called Perfected Immortals.
As the *Names of the Four Fruits* states:
The heavens possess the Two Hundred Forty Precepts of Upper Clarity
To restrain their inhabitants.
When the great kalpa’s flood arises from the Eastern Well,
Mighty springs churn the waves,
Inundating the world,
Rising to the Ultimate Wind Heaven,
Where the primordial qi dissolves,
And these heavens collapse.

A hymn says:
Through diligent cultivation of merit and conduct, one first transcends the dust,

The heart-mirror, a single wheel, diligently wipe and polish;

Beyond the Void, transcending the Heng Heaven,

**The Edict to Demons for Protecting the Dao (266 words):**
Having clarified the ranks and exhorted cultivation, we now inspect and command the spirits, sweeping away demonic trials to shield and support the adepts.

*Collation:* This is the fourth of eight sections in the *Qingyuan Sutra Commentary*.

Today, we joyfully receive deliverance, passing through the barriers of all heavens. We beseech the eradication of the Three Evils, the severance of earthly roots, the flight beyond the Five Gates, and the inscription of our names in the Great Mystery. Demon kings oversee and endorse, unhindered at the gates of heaven.

When one commits unwholesome deeds, the hun-soul grows wrathful, and the spirits depart the body, knowing it will descend into evil destinies. If one performs all wholesome acts, the hun-soul rejoices, and a hundred spirits gather, knowing it will attain the Dao. When an adept finally achieves perfection and receives deliverance, the hundred bones and myriad spirits exult together.

"Today" refers to the day of attaining the Dao. Those who seek immortality must sever their evil roots, dissolve their karmic stains, and purify their bodily vessel to attain transcendence. Thus, the Heavenly Worthy declares that on this day of joyful deliverance, one must pass through the barriers of all heavens, personally pay homage to the great emperors, beseech the eradication of the Three Wretched Paths, and cut off the karmic roots held by the Earth Bureau. One avoids the Five Sufferings, records one’s name in the register of the Great Mystery Capital, and is inscribed in the immortal roster. Thereupon, the demon kings of all heavens supervise and endorse the perfected, with no obstruction at the gates of heaven.

**Eulogy:**
Having traversed the arduous roads of all barriers,
This time, one’s name is joyfully inscribed on the golden tablet.
Who can restrain the aspirations of a true person?
Returning in glory, one moves freely with the four-horse chariot.

The Eastern Dipper governs fate-calculation; the Western Dipper records names; the Northern Dipper decrees death; the Southern Dipper bestows life; the Central Dipper, the Great Chief, oversees all spirits.

The Azure Emperor guards the hun-soul; the White Emperor attends the po-soul; the Vermilion Emperor nurtures qi; the Black Emperor circulates blood; the Yellow Emperor presides at the center, governing the myriad spirits without exception.

The Eastern Dipper’s nine stars generate qi, thus governing life-calculation. The Western Dipper’s five stars form shapes, thus recording names. The Northern Dipper’s seven stars hold the mandate of life, thus decreeing death. The Southern Dipper’s six stars enforce prohibitions, thus bestowing life. The Central Dipper’s five stars, the Great Chief, thus oversee the hundred bones and myriad spirits.

For one’s cultivation, names must be inscribed in the Five Dippers before descending spirits guard and protect, enabling the attainment of the Dao. This is the Heavenly Worthy’s salvific embrace to safeguard adepts.

Each Dipper’s apex has an emperor. When the Five Emperors reside in heaven, they govern the Three Realms, commanding all spirits without transgression. When their qi descends into the human body, it circulates through the Three Fields, regulating the Five Qi. Thus, the Azure Emperor governs the liver and guards the hun-soul; the White Emperor governs the lungs and attends the po-soul; the Vermilion Emperor governs the heart and nurtures qi; the Black Emperor governs the kidneys and circulates blood. The Yellow Emperor presides at the center in the Yellow Court, governing the hundred bones, ensuring the myriad spirits do not err.

Qi that is pure and ascends is called celestial yang; qi that is turbid and descends is called terrestrial yin; that in between is called numinous yin. The Dao of yang is divided into upper, middle, and lower, yet its function is one. The Five Directions and Five Viscera each transmit a qi, merging into one, congealing into the perfected—termed *Lingbao* (Numinous Treasure). Thus, when the five spirits are tranquil, the myriad qi flow unimpeded; when the Three Fields ascend and descend, the spirits become pure and unified. When spirits are pure and unified, they merge with the Dao and attain truth, achieving immortality. All these elucidate how *Lingbao* regulates spirits and protects the Dao for adepts.

The Primordial Cavern’s Jade Chronicle spans from Dragon Han to Yan Kang, through countless eons, within the primordial chaos. Above, there was no longer any color; below, no longer any abyss.

The Primordial Cavern refers to the ancestral qi of the Primordial Great Cavern. The Jade Chronicle records the rise and fall of celestial perfected beings’ merits, as well as the cycles of kalpas and deliverance. Beginning in Dragon Han and ending in Yan Kang, heaven and earth are generated and completed. How many times have they formed and dissolved? No memory remains—thus, it is called "countless." With each kalpic dissolution, heaven and earth scatter, mountains and seas melt away, all phenomena vanish, leaving no forms. Only the qi of the Primordial Cavern remains undifferentiated, the primordial chaos beginning to take shape. Thus, it is called "primordial chaos." At this time, the true unity of water was obscurely contained, and the Five Phases had not yet taken form. Above, no visible colors; below, no fathomable abyss. Wind and marsh pervade the void, the adamantine qi rides the heavens. Between heaven above and heaven below, there is no darkness, no obscurity, no form, no shadow, no limit, no end—vast and boundless, the Great Brahma, empty and lightless.

Wind is wood; marsh is water. Above wind, below water, empty and void, the qi fans and moistens, and the adamantine qi bears the root of heaven. The forms of heaven and earth begin to appear here. Darkness and obscurity refer to concealment and revelation; form and shadow refer to phenomena.

The term "utmost extremity" refers to the boundaries of division. "Míng-xìng" denotes vast and boundless expanse. Within primordial chaos, above heaven and below heaven, all was formless and indistinct—how could there be distinction between concealment and revelation, or between phenomena and their boundaries? Only the qi of the Great Brahma, vast and boundless, accomplished its work of itself; desolate and expansive, it remained without light or shadow.

Later, when the qi of the adamantine wind intermingled, fire was generated. The Four Symbols transformed and combined, and earth naturally took form, broadly supporting heaven and earth and nurturing the myriad beings, becoming the master of creation. Once the Five Phases were distinguished, the Two Modes began to separate. Thus, yang qi ascended to form heaven, and yin qi descended to become earth—this is the Dao of heaven and earth through the mutual generation of the Five Phases.

Moreover, the Three Realms’ perfected immortals transcend calamitous kalpas as easily as turning one’s palm, like the passing of spring and autumn in the world. Yet sentient beings, sunk in the cycle of birth and death, revolve endlessly—just so.

When the Red Clarity unfolded its chart, the revolutions proceeded naturally. In the first year of the Red Clarity, the great revolution unveiled the chart, the jade calendar fixed the epochs, and heaven and earth opened anew. Thereupon, heaven and earth, sun and moon, stars and constellations, mountains and rivers, and all phenomena were at once distinguished. Day and night, cold and heat, the four seasons advanced in succession, each finding its proper place without error—hence it is said the revolutions proceed naturally.

In the world, one *jiazi* cycle marks a minor transformation; one hundred years, a mid-term; five hundred years, a great transformation. Ten great transformations make a minor kalpa; three minor kalpas make a great kalpa—this is the pattern of kalpas without end.

The qi of primordial chaos descends as an omen, giving rise to the Five Phases, and in its cyclical return becomes the beginning and end of heaven and earth. It is like a person in the womb, gradually taking shape and gaining consciousness, the five viscera unfolding and transforming, with the cinnabar field as their foundation, nurturing the millet pearl—this alone is wondrous.

If one refines and forges the treasure through the qi of the Red Clarity, the revolutions proceed without error, naturally harmonizing with the Dao, forever becoming a perfected person, unbound by this kalpic revolution.

**Eulogy:**
The kalpic revolutions of heaven and earth share the same pattern as humanity—
Transformation and destruction are impermanent, beginning and ending in cycles.
Only the single numinous treasure remains,
Radiant and resplendent, eternally enduring.

The Primordial Beginning settled and stabilized, unfolding the Five Chapters. The red-script jade characters, the eight mighty dragon scripts, govern and restrain the kalpic revolutions, ensuring the heavens endure forever.

Once heaven and earth were established, they remained subject to kalpic revolutions. The Primordial Beginning observed the shaping of Brahma’s qi and carved jade into cloud-seal script to stabilize the Brahma heavens. Having undergone refinement by fire, it is called the "Red Script." Inscribed as the numinous treasure texts, they fully contain the wondrous, primordial, divine, and true Dao—hence the Five Chapters.

One serves to restrain kalpic disasters; another to uplift those of lower attainment, enabling scholars to awaken to its wonders and enter its wonders, awaken to its primordiality and enter its primordiality, awaken to its divinity and enter its divinity, awaken to its truth and enter its truth, awaken to its Dao and enter its Dao. The Brahma-conduct, the balanced scales of sound—

I possess the hymns of the Hollow Cavern,
Myriad transformations perfect immortals.
The immortal Dao values deliverance,
The ghost Dao clings to connection.
Heaven and earth are faint and vast,
Impure qi swirls thickly.
The joys of the three realms
Pass by, yet endure.
Deliver your body through my realm,
Your form enters spontaneity.
This joy
Is but slight grace from me.
The Dragon Han era flows boundlessly—
How can one distinguish the true?
My realm is difficult to deliver,
Thus I compose the hymns of the Hollow Cavern.
Transforming and flying through the void,
To test your body.

Laughing at your failure to be delivered,

This celestial realm stretches vast and lofty, its luminous qi radiant in the four directions—transformed from the pure qi of Brahma, it pervades the ten directions. The boundless great spirits are but the illusory forms of heavenly demonic trials, hence it is said they all arise from my body. The Dao of immortals favors deliverance; through these Hollow Cavern hymns, one may forget the dust of form, transcend both emptiness and existence, and ascend into the Three Clarities. Yet heavenly beings mistake their joy for true bliss, unaware of their direction—thus it is said the immortal Dao values deliverance. The ghostly Dao ever clings to them, for advancement leads to immortality, while retreat leads to ghosthood; between progress and withdrawal, one must choose for oneself.

Between heaven and earth, the vastness is profound, impure qi thickly accumulates, and though the realm of form brings joy, it still harbors the suffering of kalpic disasters and falls—loss comes all too easily. One must forget the defilements of the dust, ascend into the Three Realms, and only then may one endure. To be delivered through this realm is to enter the true form of spontaneity; in that moment, neither birth nor extinction arises, and all becomes joy. My grace refers to the dust of form; it is precisely by transcending this dust that one attains it.

The Dragon Han is the Dao of the Jade Clarity’s supreme sages. Boundless and without limit, all may realize it, yet now you take joy only in the realm of form—thus truth and falsehood blur, and I compose these Hollow Cavern hymns to exhort you. Through myriad transformations, demons test heavenly beings; among them, the lax are many, the ascendant few. Laughing at your failure to seek self-deliverance, I speak these words.

**Hymn:**
Men say this realm is most difficult to cross,
I say the dust of form is easily dissolved.
If but your heart were iron,
Let the furnace’s fire forge and burn.

My realm is governed,
Inheriting the Mysterious Capital.
Those who transgress my realm

I, the supreme king,
Correct and govern all demons.
In the void’s myriad transformations,
Impure qi blooms in profusion.
Those who preserve truth are few,
Those who stray and delude are many.

The ghostly Dao easily turns to evil.

The beings of this realm, though they leave form and forget the dust, have not yet attained the ultimate Dao. Through clinging to demons, they are instead burdened by them—thus the Heavenly King sets forth the way of correction, seeking to awaken them. Above the Three Realms, only the vast Celestial Net of the formless origin remains, its cloud-layers towering, beyond the gaze of lesser immortals. It is governed by the Jade Capital; beyond this boundary lies the realm of the Jade Void. Though heavenly beings have left defilement and forgotten form, they have not yet relinquished their attachments, for the mind’s perceptions remain a hindrance. To contemplate emptiness and enter subtlety is yet more difficult. Thus the ghostly Dao is easily embraced, evil enters through desire, while true beings forget the mind through self-abandonment—truly, it does not depend on external matters. The immortal Dao values substance, the human Dao values splendor. If you, heavenly beings, do not advance toward the true immortal Dao, how then can you transcend the Three Realms?
