chunks.original_text: 天中空洞，自然灵章。 诸天隐韵，天中之音，天中之尊，天中之神，天中大魔，天中之灵，九和十合，变化上清，无量之奥，深不可详，敷落神真，普度天人。 天尊所说诸天诸帝，皆是空洞之炁，自然结成。 隐文，帝魔神灵尊之秘，神灵凭之而变化，游空飞行於上清，乃九和十合之歌音，非文辞之比也。 敷者，布也； 落者，置也，皆元始开化而述布置於诸天，使执持天炁以度天人也。 颂曰： 一层天有一般名，只要修行不染尘。 直到诸天最高处，始知平育作真人。 参校曰：三十二天，有欲界、色界、无色界、种民天四者之分。 《青元经注》备述学人内功外行升进之序甚详。 愚尝参考道经释典，述成修证品，附于经卷之后。 敕魔护道二百六十六言。 前明品位劝修，今当检敕神灵，扫荡魔试，扶卫学人。 参校曰：此《青元》注经，条分八事之四也。 今日欣庆受度，历关诸天。 请灭三恶，斩绝地根，飞度五户，名列太玄。 魔王监举，无拘天门。 夫人作诸不善，则魂怒而神灵去体，知其同入恶道故也。 若作一切善，则魂喜而百灵集，知其同证道故也。 修学之士，一旦成真受度，则百骸众神，欣然而相庆也。 今日者，谓成道之日也。 人之求仙，须得恶根斩绝，罪垢消泯，使身器清净，乃得仙度。 故天尊言今日欣庆受度，则必历关于诸天，亲谒大帝，请灭三途之恶难，断绝地司之罪根； 不历五苦，纪名字於太玄都司，注定仙籍。 於是诸天魔王监真保举，更无拘滞於天门。 颂曰： 历尽关山道路辛，这回金榜喜题名。 男儿志气谁能御，驷马荣归自在行。 东斗主算，西斗记名，北斗落死，南斗上生； 中斗大魁，总监众灵。 青帝护魂，白帝侍魄，赤帝养气，黑帝通血，黄帝中主，万神无越。 东斗九星，斗中生气，故主生算。 西斗五星，斗中成形，故主记名。 北斗七星，斗中司命，故主落死。 南斗六星，斗中司禁，故主上生。 中斗五星，斗中大魁，故总监百骸众灵也。 夫人之修学，必得五斗标名，然后降神守护，乃得成道，此天尊救摄，以保学人也。 斗中之极，各有一帝。 五帝在天，则总御三界，制主万神，不使过越分度。 若降炁在人身中，则往返三田，调御五炁，故青帝治肝而护魂，白帝治肺而侍魄，赤帝治心而养气，黑帝治肾而通血； 黄帝中主於黄堂，制御百骸，万神不使错越也。 且炁清而上者曰天阳，炁之浊而下者曰地阴，其中曰灵阴。 阳之道，上中下三分，其用则一。 五方五脏各传一炁，交合为一，凝而成真，号曰灵宝。 故云五神安静，则万炁流通； 三田升降，则神灵纯一。 神灵纯一则与道合真，长生不死。 此皆显明灵宝为学人调神护道之事。 青天魔王巴元丑伯，赤天魔王负天担石，白天魔王反山六目，黑天魔王监丑朗馥，黄天魔王横天担力。 五帝大魔万神之宗，飞行鼓从，总领鬼兵，麾幢鼓节，游观太空，自号赫奕，诸天齐功。 青天魔王，青面朱发，总统九丑，游空飞行，是名巴元丑伯，皆其隐讳也。 若降炁人身，耗人肝气，使人喜愠不常。 赤天魔王负荷元炁，撑主天地，力可摧山，是名负天担石。 耗人心气，令人强暴。 白天魔王一首六目，力破山岳，游行三界，遏人善功，是名反山六目，耗人肺气，令人食恣。
chunks.translated_text:
Within the heavens lies the Hollow Cavern, where the numinous scriptures arise naturally. The hidden melodies of all heavens, the sounds within the heavens, the revered within the heavens, the spirits within the heavens, the great demons within the heavens, the numina within the heavens—nine harmonies and ten unions transform into the Supreme Clarity, boundless in mystery and too profound to expound in full. They unfold and settle the divine perfected, universally delivering the celestial beings.

The Heavenly Worthy expounds that all heavens and emperors are formed from the qi of the Hollow Cavern, spontaneously coalescing. These concealed writings are the secrets of emperors, demons, spirits, and the revered; the spirits rely upon them to transform, soaring through the void and flying in the Supreme Clarity. They are the chants of nine harmonies and ten unions, beyond comparison to mere words and phrases.

*"Fu"* means to spread; *"luo"* means to place. All were opened and transformed by the Primordial Beginning, who set them forth and arranged them among the heavens, enabling the holding of celestial qi to deliver celestial beings.

**Eulogy:**
Each heaven bears a distinct name,
Yet only cultivation keeps one free from dust.
Ascend to the highest realm of all heavens,
And you shall know *Pingyu* as a true person.

*Collation:* The thirty-two heavens are divided into four: the Realm of Desire, the Realm of Form, the Formless Realm, and the Heaven of Seed-People. The *Qingyuan Sutra Commentary* details the sequence of inner cultivation and outer conduct for adepts in full.

I have studied and compared Daoist scriptures and Buddhist canons, compiling a chapter on cultivation and realization, appended to the end of this sutra.

**The Edict to Demons for Protecting the Dao (266 words):**
Having clarified the ranks and exhorted cultivation, we now inspect and command the spirits, sweeping away demonic trials to shield and support the adepts.

*Collation:* This is the fourth of eight sections in the *Qingyuan Sutra Commentary*.

Today, we joyfully receive deliverance, passing through the barriers of all heavens. We beseech the eradication of the Three Evils, the severance of earthly roots, the flight beyond the Five Gates, and the inscription of our names in the Great Mystery. Demon kings oversee and endorse, unhindered at the gates of heaven.

When one commits unwholesome deeds, the hun-soul grows wrathful, and the spirits depart the body, knowing it will descend into evil destinies. If one performs all wholesome acts, the hun-soul rejoices, and a hundred spirits gather, knowing it will attain the Dao. When an adept finally achieves perfection and receives deliverance, the hundred bones and myriad spirits exult together.

"Today" refers to the day of attaining the Dao. Those who seek immortality must sever their evil roots, dissolve their karmic stains, and purify their bodily vessel to attain transcendence. Thus, the Heavenly Worthy declares that on this day of joyful deliverance, one must pass through the barriers of all heavens, personally pay homage to the great emperors, beseech the eradication of the Three Wretched Paths, and cut off the karmic roots held by the Earth Bureau. One avoids the Five Sufferings, records one’s name in the register of the Great Mystery Capital, and is inscribed in the immortal roster. Thereupon, the demon kings of all heavens supervise and endorse the perfected, with no obstruction at the gates of heaven.

**Eulogy:**
Having traversed the arduous roads of all barriers,
This time, one’s name is joyfully inscribed on the golden tablet.
Who can restrain the aspirations of a true person?
Returning in glory, one moves freely with the four-horse chariot.

The Eastern Dipper governs fate-calculation; the Western Dipper records names; the Northern Dipper decrees death; the Southern Dipper bestows life; the Central Dipper, the Great Chief, oversees all spirits.

The Azure Emperor guards the hun-soul; the White Emperor attends the po-soul; the Vermilion Emperor nurtures qi; the Black Emperor circulates blood; the Yellow Emperor presides at the center, governing the myriad spirits without exception.

The Eastern Dipper’s nine stars generate qi, thus governing life-calculation. The Western Dipper’s five stars form shapes, thus recording names. The Northern Dipper’s seven stars hold the mandate of life, thus decreeing death. The Southern Dipper’s six stars enforce prohibitions, thus bestowing life. The Central Dipper’s five stars, the Great Chief, thus oversee the hundred bones and myriad spirits.

For one’s cultivation, names must be inscribed in the Five Dippers before descending spirits guard and protect, enabling the attainment of the Dao. This is the Heavenly Worthy’s salvific embrace to safeguard adepts.

Each Dipper’s apex has an emperor. When the Five Emperors reside in heaven, they govern the Three Realms, commanding all spirits without transgression. When their qi descends into the human body, it circulates through the Three Fields, regulating the Five Qi. Thus, the Azure Emperor governs the liver and guards the hun-soul; the White Emperor governs the lungs and attends the po-soul; the Vermilion Emperor governs the heart and nurtures qi; the Black Emperor governs the kidneys and circulates blood. The Yellow Emperor presides at the center in the Yellow Court, governing the hundred bones, ensuring the myriad spirits do not err.

Qi that is pure and ascends is called celestial yang; qi that is turbid and descends is called terrestrial yin; that in between is called numinous yin. The Dao of yang is divided into upper, middle, and lower, yet its function is one. The Five Directions and Five Viscera each transmit a qi, merging into one, congealing into the perfected—termed *Lingbao* (Numinous Treasure). Thus, when the five spirits are tranquil, the myriad qi flow unimpeded; when the Three Fields ascend and descend, the spirits become pure and unified. When spirits are pure and unified, they merge with the Dao and attain truth, achieving immortality. All these elucidate how *Lingbao* regulates spirits and protects the Dao for adepts.

The Azure Heaven Demon King, Bayuan Choubo; the Vermilion Heaven Demon King, Futian Danshi; the White Heaven Demon King, Fanshan Liumu; the Black Heaven Demon King, Jianchou Langfu; the Yellow Heaven Demon King, Hengtian Danli. The Five Great Demon Emperors are the ancestors of all spirits, flying and drumming in procession, commanding ghostly legions, wielding banners and drums, roaming the great void, self-proclaimed as resplendent, their merits equaling all heavens.

The Azure Heaven Demon King has a green face and crimson hair, commanding the Nine Uglies, soaring through the void—his hidden name is Bayuan Choubo. When his qi descends into the human body, it depletes liver qi, causing erratic joy and anger.

The Vermilion Heaven Demon King bears primordial qi, propping up heaven and earth, his strength capable of toppling mountains—his hidden name is Futian Danshi. He depletes heart qi, making one violent.

The White Heaven Demon King has one head and six eyes, his strength shattering mountains, roaming the Three Realms, obstructing good deeds—his hidden name is Fanshan Liumu. He depletes lung qi, making one gluttonous.

chunks.original_text: 黑天魔王形质狞恶，监领小丑，性好杀伐，是名监丑朗馥。 耗人肾气，令人好杀。 黄天魔王常乘羽车，飞行三界，横行天地，举唱谣歌，恼乱学人，是名横天担力。 耗人脾气，令人灾病。 此五帝大魔，即天王也。 现魔王相，魔试学人，人若识之，与彼俱化，其魔各现帝相，升度尔身。 今以天尊开化度人摄之故，於是飞行鼓从，总领其下所辖魔兵麾幢鼓节，周游观察於太空，自行号令，威灵赫奕，与诸天等伦，代天尊开化，游行乾坤，扫荡诸魔，升度学人也。 颂曰： 名日天王复号魔，横行天地破山河。 被予识得渠名姓，倒却旗枪挂玉珂。 上天度人，严摄北酆； 神公受命，普扫不祥。 八威吐毒，猛马四张，天丁前驱，大帅仗旛，掷火万里，流铃八冲。 敢有干试，拒遏上真，金钺前戮，巨天后刑，屠割鬼爽，风火无停，千千截首，万万剪形。 魔无干犯，鬼无妖精，三官北酆，明检鬼营，不得容隐，金马驿呈。 普告无穷，万神咸听。 三界五帝，列言上清。 以度人故，严行检摄三界邪魔也。 且北都罗酆有六天洞宫，一宫各有一大魔王，司之部属甚多，不可数穷，耗人为事，忏恼学人，皆所致之。 故天尊摄之，以保学人也。 神公者，玉清丞相，受天尊敕，宣布号令，挥斥不祥。 八威者，巨虬、狮子、毒龙、猛虎、玄豹、丹蛇、麒麟、巨獬，吐毒而收邪。 天马四布，天丁前驱而禀命，大帅仗幡而领行； 烈火一掷则飞扬万里，流铃一震则交错八冲。 敢有干试，拒遏上帝真命，则天丁执金铁而前戮，力士持巨天之斧而后刑，屠割鬼爽，如风而不停。 以严速，故重云：千千截首，万万剪形，魔无干犯而扰。 正鬼无妖，沴而为精。 三官府署，北都洞宫，各明检鬼营，不容隐停。 金龙驿递而传行，普告无穷世界，三界万神，咸使闻知。 如是扫荡既毕，然后三界诸神、五方五帝言功於上清。 此皆天尊制教，为学人扫魔卫体之事。 人若内境融寂，神灵咸布，入大定相，则万邪不干，魔试消灭矣。 颂曰： 学道须凭慧力多，清江母或涨风波。 融心直入丹霞外，满目戈矛奈我何。 元始无量度人上品妙经注卷中竟 元始无量度人上品妙经注卷下 元始演法炼真保度章 众生执相，难造玄微，故重演混元，显陈模范也。 参校曰：此青元注经，表二章之第二也。 天地运度八十八言。 前者制魔护道，今当再肇生成，的彰灵宝作用。 参校曰：此青元注经，条分八事之五也。 元洞玉历，龙汉延康，眇眇亿劫，混沌之中，上无复色，下 无复渊。 元洞者，元始大洞之祖炁也。 玉历者，大洞启运，纪述天真功绩升降，及劫运度数之事也。 始於龙汉，终於延康，天地生成； 几成几坏，莫可 记忆，故云眇眇。 每一劫坏，则天地荡散，山海消融，物象一空，无复形质，但元洞之炁混然不分，沌然始构者也。 故云混沌。 当此之时，暗包真一之水，而五行未胚，故上无色象可见，下无渊极能窥。 风泽洞虚，金刚乘天。 天上天下，无幽无冥，无形无影，无极无穷，溟 音茗 涬胡颂切 大梵，寥廓无光。 风，木也； 泽，水也。 上风下水，空洞虚无，随炁扇润，而金刚之炁乘载天根，天地之形於斯始见。 幽冥者，隐显之谓也。 形影者，物象之谓也。
chunks.translated_text:
The Black Heaven Demon King has a fierce and malevolent form, overseeing lesser uglies, delighting in slaughter—his hidden name is Jianchou Langfu. He depletes kidney qi, making one fond of killing. The Yellow Heaven Demon King often rides a feathered chariot, soaring through the Three Realms, traversing heaven and earth, singing lewd songs to harass and confuse learners—his hidden name is Hengtian Danli. He depletes spleen qi, bringing misfortune and illness.

These Five Great Demon Emperors are the Heavenly Kings. When they manifest as demon kings, they test learners. If one recognizes them, they transform together, and the demons each reveal their imperial forms to ascend and deliver the learner. Now, by the grace of the Heavenly Worthy’s transformation and deliverance, they are gathered and subdued. Thus, the flying drums and banners lead their subordinate demon soldiers, roaming and inspecting the great void, issuing commands with resplendent might, equal to all heavens. On behalf of the Heavenly Worthy, they traverse the cosmos, sweeping away demons and delivering learners.

A hymn says:
Named Heavenly Kings yet called demons,
Traversing heaven and earth, shattering mountains and rivers.
Once I recognize their names,
Their banners and spears topple, jade ornaments hang still.

The heavens deliver humanity, strictly governing the Northern Feng;
Divine Lords receive the mandate, universally sweeping away misfortune.
The Eight Awes spew venom, fierce steeds spread in four directions,
Heavenly Soldiers lead the vanguard, Great Marshals wield banners,
Hurling fire for ten thousand miles, ringing bells in eight directions.
Should any dare to challenge or obstruct the Perfected of the Highest,
Golden axes strike first, the Great Heavenly Punishment follows,
Slaughtering ghostly spirits, wind and fire unceasing,
Thousands upon thousands beheaded, myriads upon myriads dismembered.
Demons dare not intrude, ghosts dare not bewitch,
The Three Offices and Northern Feng inspect ghostly camps,
No concealment allowed, reported by the Golden Horse Post.
Universally proclaimed without end, all spirits heed.

The Three Realms and Five Emperors report to the Highest Clarity,
For the sake of delivering humanity, strictly governing and subduing the demons of the Three Realms.

Moreover, in the Northern Capital of Fengdu, there are six celestial cavern palaces, each presided over by a great demon king, with countless subordinate minions. They deplete people and harass learners—all such afflictions stem from them. Thus, the Heavenly Worthy subdues them to protect learners.

The Divine Lords are the Chancellors of Jade Clarity, receiving the Heavenly Worthy’s decree to proclaim commands and dispel misfortune. The Eight Awes are the giant horned dragon, lion, poisonous dragon, fierce tiger, dark leopard, cinnabar serpent, qilin, and giant xiezhi, spewing venom to subdue evil. Heavenly steeds spread in four directions, Heavenly Soldiers lead the vanguard to receive orders, Great Marshals wield banners to command the march. A single cast of raging fire soars for ten thousand miles; a single shake of the ringing bells clashes in eight directions. Should any dare to challenge or obstruct the true mandate of the Supreme Emperor, Heavenly Soldiers wielding golden axes strike first, while Mighty Warriors brandish the Great Heavenly Axes to mete out punishment. Ghostly spirits are slaughtered without pause, swift as the wind. Thus, it is reiterated: thousands upon thousands beheaded, myriads upon myriads dismembered, demons dare not intrude or disturb. True ghosts, devoid of malevolence, are no longer spectral. The Three Offices and cavern palaces of the Northern Capital each inspect ghostly camps, allowing no concealment or delay. Reports are transmitted by the Golden Dragon Post, universally proclaimed throughout the boundless world, so that all spirits of the Three Realms may hear. Once the sweeping is complete, the myriad spirits of the Three Realms and the Five Emperors of the Five Directions report their merits to the Highest Clarity. All this is the Heavenly Worthy’s ordained teaching, to sweep away demons and protect the bodies of learners. If one’s inner realm is harmoniously tranquil, spirit and numen fully arrayed, entering the great samadhi, then no evil can intrude, and demonic tests vanish.

A hymn says:
To learn the Dao, rely much on wisdom’s power,
Like the clear river’s mother stirring wind and waves.
Melt the heart, enter beyond the cinnabar clouds,
What can a thousand spears and halberds do to me?

The *Highest Wondrous Scripture of the Primordial Limitless Deliverance of Humanity*, Commentary, Volume Two, concludes.
The *Highest Wondrous Scripture of the Primordial Limitless Deliverance of Humanity*, Commentary, Volume Three begins.
The *Primordial Exposition of the Dao for Refining the True and Preserving Deliverance* Chapter.

Sentient beings cling to forms, making it difficult to fathom the subtle and profound. Thus, the Primordial is re-explained in its undifferentiated state, clearly presenting the model.

Collated note: This is the second chapter of the *Qingyuan* Commentary on the Scripture.
The cyclical evolution of heaven and earth spans eighty-eight words. Previously, demons were subdued to protect the Dao; now, the generation and completion of life are re-initiated, distinctly manifesting the efficacy of the Numinous Treasure.

Collated note: This is the fifth of eight sections in the *Qingyuan* Commentary on the Scripture.
The Primordial Cavern’s Jade Chronicle spans from Dragon Han to Yan Kang, through countless eons, within the primordial chaos. Above, there was no longer any color; below, no longer any abyss.

The Primordial Cavern refers to the ancestral qi of the Primordial Great Cavern. The Jade Chronicle records the rise and fall of celestial perfected beings’ merits, as well as the cycles of kalpas and deliverance. Beginning in Dragon Han and ending in Yan Kang, heaven and earth are generated and completed. How many times have they formed and dissolved? No memory remains—thus, it is called "countless." With each kalpic dissolution, heaven and earth scatter, mountains and seas melt away, all phenomena vanish, leaving no forms. Only the qi of the Primordial Cavern remains undifferentiated, the primordial chaos beginning to take shape. Thus, it is called "primordial chaos." At this time, the true unity of water was obscurely contained, and the Five Phases had not yet taken form. Above, no visible colors; below, no fathomable abyss. Wind and marsh pervade the void, the adamantine qi rides the heavens. Between heaven above and heaven below, there is no darkness, no obscurity, no form, no shadow, no limit, no end—vast and boundless, the Great Brahma, empty and lightless.

Wind is wood; marsh is water. Above wind, below water, empty and void, the qi fans and moistens, and the adamantine qi bears the root of heaven. The forms of heaven and earth begin to appear here. Darkness and obscurity refer to concealment and revelation; form and shadow refer to phenomena.

chunks.original_text: 穷极者分际之谓也。 溟涬者，旷荡之谓也。 当其混沌之中，天上天下，块然无形，孰有隐显物象分际之别？ 惟大梵之炁，溟溟涬涬，自成其功； 寥兮廓兮，未有光影。 及后金风之炁相摩，乃生其火； 四象化合，土自生成，博载天地，长养万物，为造化之主也。 五行既判，二仪始分，於是阳炁上而成天，阴炁下而为地，即五行相生，天地之道也。 且三境高真过度灾劫，如阅世之春秋，易於反掌。 而众生沉滞生死，轮转无穷，亦如是也。 赤明开图，运度自然。 至赤明元年，大运启图，玉历定纪，天地再开。 於是天地、日月、星辰、山川、物象一时分判，昼夜寒暑四序推迁，各得其所，冈有差忒，故云运度自然。 凡世间一甲子为一小变，一百年为中期，五百年为一大变，十变为一小劫，三小劫为一大劫，此亿劫之例也。 混洞之炁降兆，生成五行，返覆为天地之终始。 如人在胞胎，渐分形识，五脏布化，以丹田为基，长养黍珠，惟此为妙。 假赤明之炁煅炼成宝，运度无差，自然合道，永作真人，不拘此劫运也。 颂曰： 乾坤劫运与人同，变灭无常始复终。 惟有一灵真宝物，光明烜赫镇无穷。 元始安镇，敷落五篇。 赤书玉字，八威龙文。 保制劫运，使天长存。 天地既立，犹拘劫运，元始乃观梵炁之结形，刻玉为云篆，以镇梵天，已经火炼，故曰赤书。 着成灵宝之文，具载妙元神真道，故曰五篇。 一以保制劫灾。 一以提拔下士，俾夫学者悟其妙者入其妙，悟其元者入其元，悟其神者入其神，悟其真者入其真，悟其道者入其道，然后尽妙合元，尽元合神，尽神合真，尽真合道，自然无毁无灭，超出度数，与天长存。 颂曰： 五篇文字隐玄功，保制灾危镇梵宫。
chunks.translated_text:
The term "utmost extremity" refers to the boundaries of division. "Míng-xìng" denotes vast and boundless expanse. Within primordial chaos, above heaven and below heaven, all was formless and indistinct—how could there be distinction between concealment and revelation, or between phenomena and their boundaries? Only the qi of the Great Brahma, vast and boundless, accomplished its work of itself; desolate and expansive, it remained without light or shadow.

Later, when the qi of the adamantine wind intermingled, fire was generated. The Four Symbols transformed and combined, and earth naturally took form, broadly supporting heaven and earth and nurturing the myriad beings, becoming the master of creation. Once the Five Phases were distinguished, the Two Modes began to separate. Thus, yang qi ascended to form heaven, and yin qi descended to become earth—this is the Dao of heaven and earth through the mutual generation of the Five Phases.

Moreover, the Three Realms’ perfected immortals transcend calamitous kalpas as easily as turning one’s palm, like the passing of spring and autumn in the world. Yet sentient beings, sunk in the cycle of birth and death, revolve endlessly—just so.

When the Red Clarity unfolded its chart, the revolutions proceeded naturally. In the first year of the Red Clarity, the great revolution unveiled the chart, the jade calendar fixed the epochs, and heaven and earth opened anew. Thereupon, heaven and earth, sun and moon, stars and constellations, mountains and rivers, and all phenomena were at once distinguished. Day and night, cold and heat, the four seasons advanced in succession, each finding its proper place without error—hence it is said the revolutions proceed naturally.

In the world, one *jiazi* cycle marks a minor transformation; one hundred years, a mid-term; five hundred years, a great transformation. Ten great transformations make a minor kalpa; three minor kalpas make a great kalpa—this is the pattern of kalpas without end.

The qi of primordial chaos descends as an omen, giving rise to the Five Phases, and in its cyclical return becomes the beginning and end of heaven and earth. It is like a person in the womb, gradually taking shape and gaining consciousness, the five viscera unfolding and transforming, with the cinnabar field as their foundation, nurturing the millet pearl—this alone is wondrous.

If one refines and forges the treasure through the qi of the Red Clarity, the revolutions proceed without error, naturally harmonizing with the Dao, forever becoming a perfected person, unbound by this kalpic revolution.

**Eulogy:**
The kalpic revolutions of heaven and earth share the same pattern as humanity—
Transformation and destruction are impermanent, beginning and ending in cycles.
Only the single numinous treasure remains,
Radiant and resplendent, eternally enduring.

The Primordial Beginning settled and stabilized, unfolding the Five Chapters. The red-script jade characters, the eight mighty dragon scripts, govern and restrain the kalpic revolutions, ensuring the heavens endure forever.

Once heaven and earth were established, they remained subject to kalpic revolutions. The Primordial Beginning observed the shaping of Brahma’s qi and carved jade into cloud-seal script to stabilize the Brahma heavens. Having undergone refinement by fire, it is called the "Red Script." Inscribed as the numinous treasure texts, they fully contain the wondrous, primordial, divine, and true Dao—hence the Five Chapters.

One serves to restrain kalpic disasters; another to uplift those of lower attainment, enabling scholars to awaken to its wonders and enter its wonders, awaken to its primordiality and enter its primordiality, awaken to its divinity and enter its divinity, awaken to its truth and enter its truth, awaken to its Dao and enter its Dao. Only then, having fully merged wonder with primordiality, primordiality with divinity, divinity with truth, and truth with the Dao, do they naturally become indestructible and imperishable, transcending the revolutions, enduring with heaven forever.

**Eulogy:**
The Five Chapters’ texts conceal profound efficacy,
Governing and restraining calamities to stabilize the Brahma palaces.

chunks.original_text: 个是赤书真妙诀，且将符篆作形容。 参校曰：《九品仙录经》曰：昔混元溟涬，诸天未分，元始肇形，五劫初化，乃命梵元祖晨道君肇录天元，运乘五劫。 故元洞者，以成祖炁； 玉历者，以纪天元。 自一炁化分，三因成九，若龙若蜒； 蟠曲九道，漠漠无极，总九阳祖炁之元，太上以运梵合炁。 开始青天元祖炁，故东方得九炁以分天境，劫号龙汉。 又合炁开南丹天元祖炁，故南方得三炁以分 天境，劫号赤明。 又合炁开中黄天元祖炁，故中央得十二炁，以分天境，劫号上皇。 又合炁开素灵天元祖炁，故西方得七炁以分天境，劫号延康。 又合炁开北玄天元祖炁，故北方得五炁以分天境，劫号开皇。 五劫既周，昊天成象，一炁混道，八景流光。 八帝示形，九霄分化。 故元始天尊命天真皇人以玉历纪元洞之初，劫运流复之本。 诸天分境结元洞五阳之炁，为玉历，以纪天真、天民劫运功绩升退之道，明九圣九品之阶。 今附见于此。 至如亿劫年数，考究未的。 盖劫运大小不一，年数亦不一，有天地成坏劫，其最大者也。 有大劫、中劫、小劫之分，其年数多寡，上天所秘，经文所不载者，非世人所能尽知故也。 混合成真一百六十八言。 前明生成建立之规，今则的指真灵孕宝运化之妙。 参校曰：此青元注经，条分八事之六也。 梵炁弥罗，万范开张。 元纲流演，三十二天。 轮转无色，周回十方。 旋斗历箕，回度五常； 三十五分，总炁上元； 八景冥合，炁入玄玄。 梵炁者，元洞一炁之所化，先天地立，为大道根； 倏升倏腾，自浩劫来，弥覆三界，罗络诸天。 元始资之而御运，天地赖之而生成。 两仪既分，物象咸布，故为万范开张也。 梵炁为元化之纲，流演於三十二天，如轮运转自然，无色界起，周回十方，绵绵不息，从斗至箕，左历二十八宿，缠度如是一周天，应人间一岁之运。 天罡左旋，五星右转，会合成功也。 二十八宿合日月五星，故云三十五分也。 总受高上天元之炁，八景冥然交合，是谓玄功。 玄而又玄，故云玄玄。 如《生神宝章》曰：混化归玄一，高结元始王之义。 如人之身，筋昹缠布，百昹通流，元炁徘徊，一身受润，三田华素，五脏清夷，始得成真。 颂曰： 梵熙从教左右旋，须突历尽一周天。 可怜不费纤毫力，直到华胥谒上仙。 玄中太皇，上帝高真。 泛景太霞，啸咏洞章。 金真朗郁，流响云营。 玉音摄炁，灵风聚烟。 紫虚郁秀，辅翼万仙。 千和万合，自然成真。 玄者，紫微天心玄都中宫也。 太皇，即明皇道君； 上帝高真，即灵宝至真也。 言玄都中有此上真，当泛景太霞之上，啸咏大洞之章，开度学人。 於是金真结而朗郁，流声响於云营，玉音收摄於散炁，灵风混合而生烟。 徧紫虚而郁秀，乃辅翼乎万仙。 故千和而万合，成灵宝而登真。 修真之士，使梵炁回旋，帝真在定，金光朗彻，流云徘徊，自然虎啸风生，龙吟炁聚，大宝无不媾成也。 颂曰： 祖炁朝元玄又玄，太皇面目俨然全。 风烟聚散神光定，精炼成容合自然。 真中有神，长生大君，无英公子，白元尊神，太一司命，桃康合延，执符把箓，保命生根。 上游上清，出入华房。 八冥之内，细微之中，下镇人身泥丸绛宫，中理五炁，混合百神。

This is the true and wondrous oral formula of the Red Writ, whose talismanic script serves as its outward form.

**Collation Note:** As stated in *The Scripture of the Nine Grades of Immortals*: In the primordial chaos before the separation of the myriad heavens, when the Primordial Beginning first took shape and the Five Kalpas began their transformation, the Celestial Venerable of the Dawn Dao of the Brahma-Origin Ancestor was commanded to inscribe the Heavenly Origin, thereby setting in motion the revolving Five Kalpas.

Thus, the *Primal Cavern* was established to perfect the ancestral qi, while the *Jade Chronicle* was instituted to record the Heavenly Origin. From the differentiation of the One Qi, the Three Causes coalesced into the Nine, resembling dragons coiling through nine pathways—boundless and infinite—all comprising the origin of the Nine Yang’s ancestral qi. The Most High harmonized and merged them with the Brahma-qi.

First, the ancestral qi of the Azure Heavenly Origin was activated, granting the Eastern Quarter nine qi to divide its celestial realm, its kalpa named *Dragon Han*. Next, the qi were merged to activate the ancestral qi of the Vermilion Heavenly Origin in the South, granting the Southern Quarter three qi to divide its celestial realm, its kalpa named *Red Brightness*. Then, the qi were merged to activate the ancestral qi of the Central Yellow Heavenly Origin, granting the Central Quarter twelve qi to divide its celestial realm, its kalpa named *Supreme August*. Again, the qi were merged to activate the ancestral qi of the Pale-Spirit Heavenly Origin in the West, granting the Western Quarter seven qi to divide its celestial realm, its kalpa named *Prolonged Prosperity*. Finally, the qi were merged to activate the ancestral qi of the Mysterious Black Heavenly Origin in the North, granting the Northern Quarter five qi to divide its celestial realm, its kalpa named *Inaugural August*.

Once the Five Kalpas had run their course, the Vast Heaven took form, the One Qi merged with the Dao, and the Eight Radiant Sceneries streamed forth their light. The Eight Emperors manifested their forms, and the Nine Empyreans branched into differentiation. Thus, the Celestial Venerable of the Primordial Beginning commanded the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign to inscribe the *Jade Chronicle* at the inception of the *Primal Cavern*, recording the fundamental revolutions of kalpic cycles. The myriad heavens divided their realms and conjoined the Five Yang qi of the *Primal Cavern* into the *Jade Chronicle*, which documented the Way of ascent and descent for Heavenly Perfected Ones and Heavenly People based on their kalpic merits, clarifying the nine grades of the Nine Sages. This is appended here for reference. As for the reckoning of kalpic years, their exactitude remains unverified. Since kalpas vary in magnitude—great, middling, and small—their years differ as well. The greatest is the kalpa of heaven-and-earth’s formation and dissolution, while others are divided into major, intermediate, and minor kalpas. Their precise durations are secrets of the heavens, unrecorded in scriptures, and thus beyond mortal comprehension.

These truths coalesce into the One Hundred and Sixty-Eight Words of the Perfect Real. The preceding elucidates the principles of generation and establishment, while the present text precisely indicates the wondrous workings of the true numen nurturing the precious transformation.

**Collation Note:** This is the sixth of eight divisions in the Azure Origin’s annotated scripture.

The Brahma-qi pervades the cosmos, unfolding the myriad patterns. The primordial net flows and evolves, spanning the Thirty-Two Heavens. Revolving without form, it circulates through the Ten Directions. It wheels through the Dipper and traverses the Winnowing Basket, cycling through the Five Constants. In thirty-five divisions, it gathers the qi of the Upper Origin. The Eight Sceneries merge in profound obscurity, where qi enters the Mystery of Mysteries.

The Brahma-qi is the transformation of the One Qi of the *Primal Cavern*, existing before heaven and earth as the root of the Great Dao. Swiftly ascending and soaring since the primordial kalpa, it blankets the Three Realms and enmeshes the myriad heavens. The Primordial Beginning relies upon it to govern the cosmos, while heaven and earth depend on it for generation and completion. Once the Two Modes separated, all phenomena were arrayed—hence the unfolding of the myriad patterns. The Brahma-qi serves as the net of primordial transformation, flowing through the Thirty-Two Heavens like a wheel in natural motion. The Formless Realm arises, circulating through the Ten Directions in an unbroken stream. From the Dipper to the Winnowing Basket, it traverses the Twenty-Eight Constellations in a leftward cycle, completing one celestial revolution corresponding to a human year. The Celestial Stem revolves leftward, while the Five Planets turn rightward, converging to fulfill their functions. The Twenty-Eight Constellations, combined with the Sun, Moon, and Five Planets, form thirty-five divisions. Collectively, they receive the qi of the Supreme Heavenly Origin, where the Eight Sceneries merge in profound obscurity—this is called the Mysterious Work. Mysterious yet again mysterious, hence the term *Mystery of Mysteries*. As the *Precious Chapters of Spirit Generation* states: "The chaotic transformation returns to the Mysterious One, exaltedly uniting with the Primordial Beginning Sovereign." Like the human body, where sinews and vessels intertwine and the hundred vessels flow unimpeded, the primordial qi circulates, nourishing the entire body. The Three Fields flourish in purity, the Five Viscera attain clarity and harmony, and only then is perfection achieved.

**Eulogy:**
The Brahma-qi revolves as taught, left and right,
Swiftly completing one celestial cycle.
How wondrous—without the slightest effort,
It ascends to Huaxu to meet the Supreme Immortals.

Within the Mystery dwells the Supreme August, the Highest Perfected of the Celestial Emperor. They drift upon the Great Radiance, chanting and intoning the *Cavernous Chapters*. Golden perfection gleams in luxuriance, its resonance streaming through the cloudy encampments. Jade tones gather qi, while numinous winds amass mist. The Purple Void flourishes in splendor, aiding and sheltering the myriad immortals. Through a thousand harmonies and ten thousand unions, perfection is naturally achieved.

The Mystery refers to the Purple Tenuity at the heart of the Heavenly Center, the Central Palace of the Mysterious Metropolis. The Supreme August is the Illustrious August Dao Sovereign; the Highest Perfected of the Celestial Emperor are the Perfect Ones of the Numinous Treasure. Within the Mysterious Metropolis dwell these Supreme Perfected Ones, who drift upon the Great Radiance and chant the *Cavernous Chapters* to initiate and deliver learners. Thus, golden perfection coalesces in brilliance, its voice resonating through the cloudy encampments. Jade tones gather the scattered qi, while numinous winds blend to generate mist. Pervading the Purple Void in flourishing splendor, they aid and shelter the myriad immortals. Through a thousand harmonies and ten thousand unions, the Numinous Treasure is perfected, and transcendence is attained. For those who cultivate perfection, when the Brahma-qi revolves and the Celestial Emperor’s Perfected Ones abide in stillness, golden light shines in clarity, drifting clouds linger—naturally, the tiger’s roar summons the wind, the dragon’s chant gathers qi, and the Great Treasure is consummated without fail.

**Eulogy:**
The ancestral qi faces the Origin, mysterious yet again,
The Supreme August’s visage wholly preserved.
Winds and mists gather and disperse, the spirit-light steadies,
Refined into form, harmonizing with the natural.

Within the true dwells the spirit—the Great Lord of Longevity, the Peerless Duke, the Venerable White Prime, the Celestial Thearch of Grand Unity, the Longevity Directors Peach and Plum, who grasp talismans and hold registers to safeguard life and root existence. They ascend to the Upper Clarity, entering and exiting the Flowery Chambers. Within the Eight Obscurities and the subtlest realms, they descend to guard the Mud-Pellet and Crimson Palaces of the human body, governing the Five Qi and harmonizing the hundred spirits.

chunks.original_text: 长生大君乃斗中之尊星也。 太一、桃康为领卫； 无英、白元为辅宸，皆斗中真人也。 执玉符、定金箓、保人形命，主生化之根。 上则游行上清高虚之表，出入丹华之房，周极八冥，目至细微造化之内。 下则镇人身宅，或居泥丸，或住绛宫。 中则调理五运之炁，会合百神也。 若降炁在人，则为内景之精光，长生主心，白元治肺，元英居肝，太一司命，住肾； 合延桃康，主脾。 符录以喻气血斡旋，以保生根。 一则居脐，所以调理五炁； 一则升脑，所以混合百神。 交合依时，是名颠倒升降得所，是名返复。 故五行颠倒，则大宝炁足，三田返复； 则阳神上升，永为真人。 所以十转回旋，灵光褊体，万炁俱得而仙，始超无漏。 如《救苦经》云：天炁归一身，皆成自然人。 颂曰： 妙哉灵宝七般神，上通天关下微尘。 运用只凭些子诀，便超无漏作真人。 十转回灵，万炁齐仙。 十者，阴阳之成数也。 如乾九坎一成十，坤六离四，巽二兑八，艮三震七，皆合成十； 乃天地之大数，变化之根元。 所以十转回灵，则尽周天之极数，自然灵光充溢，万炁还元，各得其真也。 颂曰： 周回十过运三灵，万炁归根混一真。 这个机关能解悟，霎时天地变黄金。 参校曰：经注条分混合，成真一百六十八言。 此皆灵宝度人，炼形了命之妙。 而青元注内又发明之。 《道德经》曰：谷神不死，是谓玄牝。 此内丹归根复命之根蒂也。 盖探药而归复，入室而成胎，舞蜕而脱胎； 升顶炼形而释结，解胞瘟养而气足，形充功满而调神出壳。 《老君圣纪》有训：羽化神仙，无令断绝，丹成而蜕，蜕而腾虚御景，身外有身，是谓之仙。 近代紫阳张真人一派有《金丹四百字》、《悟真篇》、《翠虚吟》、《紫清文集》等丹经口诀，亦多显露。 如：潭底日红阴怪灭，山头月白药苗新。 归根自有归根窍，复命还寻复命关。 卯酉甲庚须沐浴，朔弦晦望每防危。 百刻寒温忙裹准，六爻文武静中看。 探药沐浴、火候抽添之真机，未尝不泄於文字间。 但禁戒至重，古今所同，魔试相干，坚定方可。 故必真践实履，积行累功，方能因缘遇合成就。 又如《参同》释祖达磨形神俱妙，只履西归之事； 《实录》中有《胎息经》略曰：玄牝之门，驻景之户。 若能兼行，自然甘露。 盖未尝非《道德经》中旨也。 又有《调神歌》一篇，与丹经调神之法合同。 其歌曰：调神如婴，万法无情。 恬如恬如，神兮自宁。 调神如婴，寒暑枯荣。 治之、覆之，形神自贞。 调神如婴，启合形神。 形神启合，如琉璃瓶。 中有金像，虚实交并。 像喻法体，瓶喻色身。 外不可染，内不可尘。 像之与瓶，皎洁分明。 不一不二，如水澄停。 无浊无清，水亦无形。 出不由户，非功非程。 镜兮若明，万像自形。 水兮若清，月影自形。 非学所得，非师所成。 如虫食木，偶然自成。 万像之形，如月之明，万法之名，如谷之声。 法本无法，名本无名，无名无法，不起神形。 形神不起，感之则生。 妄风不起，神何不宁。 善聆若聋，善视若盲。 智不如愚，老不如婴。 调之千日，自然能醒。 惺中之梦，梦中之惺。 明者不言，言者不明。 有言则漏，有漏不生。 日待朝升，我性常明。 月待圆成，我体长形。 天食滋形，含灵抱英。
chunks.translated_text:
The Great Lord of Longevity is the revered star within the Dipper. The Supreme One and Peach-Kang serve as his vanguard and guardians; the Peerless Duke and Venerable White Prime act as his ministers and attendants—all are perfected beings of the Dipper. They wield jade talismans, stabilize golden registers, safeguard the human form and destiny, and govern the root of generation and transformation. Above, they roam beyond the Upper Clarity’s lofty void, entering and exiting the Cinnabar-Flower Chambers, traversing the Eight Obscurities and the subtlest realms of creation. Below, they guard the human dwelling, residing either in the Mud-Pellet Palace or the Crimson Palace. At the center, they regulate the qi of the Five Movements and harmonize the hundred spirits.

When their qi descends into a person, it becomes the radiant essence of the inner landscape: the Great Lord of Longevity presides over the heart, the Venerable White Prime governs the lungs, the Peerless Duke resides in the liver, the Supreme One and the Longevity Directors dwell in the kidneys, while Peach-Kang and He-Yan oversee the spleen. The talismans and registers symbolize the circulation of qi and blood, preserving the root of life. One resides in the navel to regulate the Five Qi; the other ascends to the brain to harmonize the hundred spirits. Their union, timed with precision, is called "inversion and ascent-descent in proper order," or "reversion and recurrence."

Thus, when the Five Phases invert, the Great Treasure’s qi becomes full; when the Three Fields revert, the yang spirit ascends, and one forever becomes a perfected being. Through ten revolutions of circulation, the numinous light permeates the body, and the myriad qi are all attained—ascending as an immortal, transcending the leakless state. As the *Sutra of Salvation from Suffering* states: "When the celestial qi returns to the one body, all become natural beings."

**Eulogy:**
Wondrous are the Seven Numinous Treasures,
Above they reach the Celestial Pass, below the finest dust.
Their use depends on but a single secret,
And one transcends the leakless to become a perfected being.

Ten revolutions of the numinous, the myriad qi ascend as immortals.
Ten is the complete number of yin and yang: Qian nine and Kan one make ten; Kun six and Li four, Xun two and Dui eight, Gen three and Zhen seven—all combine to form ten. This is the great number of heaven and earth, the root of transformation. Thus, ten revolutions of the numinous complete the supreme cycle of the celestial sphere, naturally filling the numinous light and returning the myriad qi to their origin, each attaining its true nature.

**Eulogy:**
Ten revolutions complete the three numinous,
The myriad qi return to their root, merging into the One True.
Whoever grasps this mechanism,
In an instant, heaven and earth turn to gold.

**Collation:**
The annotations of the scripture interweave and unify, forming the True One in one hundred sixty-eight words. These are the wondrous methods of the Numinous Treasure for refining form and completing destiny, further elucidated in the *Qingyuan* commentary.

The *Dao De Jing* states: "The valley spirit does not die; it is called the Mysterious Female." This is the root of inner alchemy’s return to the origin and revival of destiny. For one gathers the medicine and returns, enters the chamber to form the embryo, sloughs the husk and emerges from the womb; ascends to the crown to refine form and release knots, dissolves the fetal toxins through nurturing until qi is full, form is replete, and merit complete—then one regulates the spirit and exits the shell. The *Sacred Records of Lord Lao* instructs: "Let the feathered transformation of immortals never cease. When the elixir is complete, one sheds the husk, ascends the void, and rides the light—possessing a body beyond the body, this is called an immortal."

The lineage of the Purple Yang Perfected Zhang in recent times has produced alchemical scriptures and oral instructions such as the *Four Hundred Words on the Golden Elixir*, the *Awakening to Reality*, the *Green Void Hymns*, and the *Purple Clarity Writings*, which also reveal much. For example:
*"At the pool’s bottom, the sun reddens and yin demons vanish;
At the mountain’s peak, the moon whitens and the medicinal sprouts renew.
Returning to the root has its returning aperture,
Reviving destiny seeks its reviving pass.
Mao and You, Jia and Geng demand bathing;
New moon, first quarter, full moon, and dark moon—each guard against peril.
A hundred moments of cold and warmth must be precisely managed,
The six lines of civil and martial observed in stillness."*

The true mechanism of gathering medicine, bathing, and fire-times with withdrawal and addition has never been concealed within the texts. Yet the prohibitions are most weighty, shared across ancient and modern times. Trials by demonic tests demand steadfast resolve. Thus, only through true practice, accumulated deeds, and layered merit can one encounter the conditions for accomplishment.

Similarly, the *Can Tong Qi* explains the matter of Bodhidharma’s wondrous union of form and spirit, returning west with a single sandal. The *Veritable Records* include a summary of the *Scripture on Embryonic Breathing*:
*"The gate of the Mysterious Female,
The portal where the radiance abides.
If one can practice both,
Naturally, the sweet dew descends."*
This is none other than the essence of the *Dao De Jing*.

There is also a *Song of Regulating the Spirit*, which aligns with the methods of regulating the spirit in the alchemical scriptures:
*"Regulate the spirit as an infant,
All dharmas are without emotion.
Serene, oh so serene—
The spirit, of itself, attains tranquility.

Regulate the spirit as an infant,
Through cold and heat, withering and flourishing.
Nurture it, shelter it—
Form and spirit, of themselves, become steadfast.

Regulate the spirit as an infant,
Uniting and parting form and spirit.
When form and spirit unite and part,
They are like a lapis lazuli bottle:
Within, a golden image,
Vacuity and fullness intermingling.

The image is the dharma-body’s metaphor,
The bottle, the physical form’s.
Externally, it cannot be stained;
Internally, it cannot gather dust.
Image and bottle,
Luminous and distinct.

Neither one nor two,
Like water, still and clear.
No turbidity, no clarity—
Water, too, has no form.
Exiting not through doors,
Neither by effort nor by method.

The mirror, if bright,
All images manifest of themselves.
The water, if clear,
The moon’s reflection appears of itself.

Not attained through study,
Not achieved by a teacher.
Like a worm eating wood,
By chance, it forms of itself.

The forms of the myriad images
Are like the moon’s brightness;
The names of the myriad dharmas
Are like the echo in a valley.

The dharma is originally without dharma,
The name originally without name.
Without name, without dharma—
Spirit and form do not arise.

When spirit and form do not arise,
Stimulated, they then arise.
If the wind of delusion does not stir,
How could the spirit not be tranquil?

Listen well yet seem deaf,
See well yet seem blind.
Wisdom is not as good as foolishness,
Age is not as good as infancy.

Regulate it for a thousand days,
And naturally, one awakens.
Awake within the dream,
Dreaming within the awake.

The enlightened do not speak,
Those who speak are not enlightened.
To speak is to leak;
With leakage, nothing is born.

The sun awaits its morning rise,
Yet my nature is ever bright.
The moon awaits its fullness,
Yet my body is eternally formed.

Heaven nourishes the form,
Embracing the numinous and holding the essence."*

chunks.original_text: 醍醐之莹，牛头之馨。 行一空味，神怡体清。 血化为乳，骨化为琼。 能狮子吼，变野牛声。 白毫生额，金仙道成。 祖师之妙，寂寂冥冥。 神不见形，形不见神。 即心无心，即形无形。 心尚不见，此外无名。 形神无主，舍识皆平。 谁健谁衰，谁灭谁生。 谁喜谁怒，谁怖谁惊。 谁念谁思，谁辱谁荣。 如日升天，自行自明。 勤而行之，祖师之程。 今附于此。 劝勉学士四百一十三言。 前明炼真轨范，今则开示勤惰，黜陟自白，重伸劝勉。 参校曰：此青元注经，条分八事之七也。 仙道贵生，无量度人。 上开八门，飞天法轮。 罪福禁戒，宿命因缘。 普受开度，死魂生身。 身得受生，上闻诸天。 诸天之上，各有生门。 中有空洞谣歌之章，魔王灵篇，辞参高真。 仙道好生，甚於之求生。 仙道度人，常欲众生不死。 而死灭之理，人世自迷。 故太上慈悲，区区至切，所以上开八门，下应八元，自八门中进修，皆可升真入妙。 法轮者，无上妙法之所，运转不息，亦开示轮回之道，设以罪福之禁戒、宿命之因缘。 皆警悟凡夫，使超出苦轮而转无尽法藏也。 於是死魂生身，皆获品度，上告诸天，随念升入诸天，各有长生之门。 升堕之格隐空洞正音谣歌之章，乃魔王之所述，劝勉学人，其辞皆与高真参合也。 颂曰： 仙道区区度学人，八门开设向迷津。 劝君只向生门入，升入诸天转法轮。 第一欲界飞空之音： 此界天人以欲乐而坠，故魔王述飞行虚空之道，使离诸欲乐，进入轻清，故云飞空。 人道眇眇，仙道莽莽，鬼道乐兮，当人生门。 仙道贵生，鬼道贵终。 仙道常自吉，鬼道常自凶。 高上清灵爽，悲歌朗太空。 唯愿仙道成，不欲人道穷。 北都泉曲府，中有万鬼群。 但欲遏人算，断绝人命门。 阿人歌洞章，以摄北罗酆。 束送妖魔精，斩馘六鬼锋。 诸天炁荡荡，我道自兴隆。 人道甚微，易失故也。 仙道莽大，易证故也。 六欲染着，易为迷惑，故云乐也。 欲之为害，当人生根； 仙道好度，使超欲乐，进入高空。 而天人欲根，未尝暂离仙鬼之道，如君子、小人，各愿为其类，相为喜也。 是以仙道尚升，鬼道尚堕； 如善人为善，惟日不足； 恶人为恶，亦惟日不足。 为仙道者，常自吉庆，为鬼道者，常自凶邪。 所谓吉者去欲而已，所谓凶者爱欲而已。 唯高上至圣言辞清灵爽秀，悲悯天人，易入鬼趣，故作空歌。 叙六欲之苦，不欲其坠也。 北都泉曲者，拘囚之所，凡天人报尽，乃入其境。 故云：中有万鬼群，但欲遏人年算，绝人命根。 欲染之乐，其报如是。 天人能保人道，深镒鬼趣，故称：阿人常歌洞章，摄伏魔类，断绝六欲之根，故云锋也。 颂曰： 六欲原从暗里来，相牵鬼道可哀哉。 君还会得悲歌意，束尽群妖道眼开。 第二色界魔王之章： 此天自以色尘为乐，故述以玉清之道，离色忘尘，升玄入妙。 落落高张，明炁四骞。 梵行 音衡 诸天，周回十方。 无量大神，皆由我身。 我有洞章，万徧成仙。 仙道贵度，鬼道相连。 天地眇莽，秽气氛氛。 三界乐兮，过之长存。 身度我界，体入自然。 此时乐兮，薄由我恩。 龙汉荡荡，何能别真。 我界难度，故作洞文。 变化飞空，以试尔身。 成败懈退，度者几人。 笑尔不度，故为歌音。
chunks.translated_text:
The clarity of ghee, the fragrance of udumbara.
Practicing the flavor of emptiness,
The spirit rejoices, the body is purified.
Blood transforms into milk,
Bones into jade.
The lion’s roar is mastered,
The wild ox’s cry is altered.
A white hair appears upon the forehead,
The Golden Immortal’s Dao is accomplished.
The wondrousness of the Patriarchs
Lies in profound stillness and darkness.
The spirit does not see the form,
The form does not see the spirit.
When the heart is without heart,
When the form is without form—
Even the heart is not seen,
What name could there be beyond this?
Form and spirit without master,
All faculties are at peace.
Who is strong? Who is weak?
Who perishes? Who is born?
Who rejoices? Who rages?
Who fears? Who startles?
Who thinks? Who ponders?
Who is humbled? Who is honored?
Like the sun ascending the heavens,
It moves of itself, illuminates of itself.
Diligently practice this,
The path of the Patriarchs.
Here it is appended.
Four hundred thirteen words to exhort and encourage scholars.

Previously, the refining of true norms was expounded;
Now, diligence and indolence are revealed,
Promotion and demotion made clear,
The exhortation reiterated.

Collated note: This is the seventh of eight sections in the *Qingyuan Annotation of the Scripture*.

The Dao of immortals values life,
Delivering boundless beings.
Above, eight gates are opened,
The Dharma-wheel of flying immortals.
Karma and precepts, karmic causes and conditions—
Universally received and delivered,
The dead soul revives in the body.
The body attains rebirth,
Ascending to be heard by the heavens.
Above the heavens,
Each has its gate of life.
Within are the hymns of the Hollow Cavern,
The sacred chapters of demon-kings,
Whose words align with the lofty perfected.

The Dao of immortals cherishes life,
More earnestly than the pursuit of life itself.
The Dao of immortals delivers beings,
Ever desiring that all living things not die.
Yet the principle of death and extinction
Is self-delusion in the human world.
Thus, the Most High, in boundless compassion,
Opens the eight gates above,
Responding to the eight origins below.
From within the eight gates, all who cultivate
May ascend to perfection and enter the wondrous.

The Dharma-wheel is the realm of the supreme wondrous Dharma,
Revolving without cease.
It also reveals the path of samsara,
Establishing precepts of karma and retribution,
Karmic causes and conditions—
All to awaken ordinary beings,
Enabling them to transcend the wheel of suffering
And turn the inexhaustible treasury of Dharma.
Thus, the dead soul revives in the body,
All attain deliverance by rank,
Ascending to report to the heavens.
Following their thoughts, they ascend into the heavens,
Each with its gate of eternal life.
The standards of ascent and descent
Are concealed within the hymns of the Hollow Cavern’s true tones,
Composed by the demon-kings
To exhort practitioners,
Their words aligning with the lofty perfected.

Verse:
The Dao of immortals, earnestly delivering scholars,
Opens eight gates toward the ford of delusion.
I urge you: enter only through the gate of life,
Ascend into the heavens and turn the Dharma-wheel.

**First: The Flying Void’s Sound of the Desire Realm**
The heavenly beings of this realm fall through desire and pleasure,
Thus the demon-king expounds the path of flying through the void,
Enabling them to leave all desires and pleasures,
Entering lightness and purity—hence, "flying void."
The human path is faint,
The immortal path vast,
The ghost path joyous—
Yet the human gate of life is paramount.
The immortal Dao values life,
The ghost Dao values death.
The immortal Dao is ever auspicious,
The ghost Dao ever inauspicious.
The lofty, pure, and numinous,
Sing sorrowful hymns in the great void.
Only wishing the immortal Dao be accomplished,
Not desiring the human path to wither.
In the Northern Capital’s Spring Bend Prefecture,
A myriad ghosts gather.
They only seek to cut short human years,
Sever the human gate of life.
Ah! Sing the hymns of the Hollow Cavern,
To subdue the Northern Feng.
Bind and send forth demonic spirits,
Sever the blades of the six ghosts.
The heavens’ qi flows boundlessly,
My Dao naturally flourishes.
The human path is subtle,
Easily lost.
The immortal Dao is vast,
Easily realized.
The six desires stain and cling,
Easily causing delusion—hence, "joyous."
The harm of desire
Lies at the root of human life.
The immortal Dao delights in deliverance,
Enabling transcendence of desire and pleasure,
Entering the high void.
Yet the heavenly beings’ root of desire
Never momentarily departs from the paths of immortals and ghosts—
Like the noble and the base,
Each delights in their kind, rejoicing together.
Thus, the immortal Dao esteems ascent,
The ghost Dao esteems descent.
Like the good who do good,
Never finding the day sufficient;
The wicked who do evil,
Also never finding the day sufficient.
Those who follow the immortal Dao
Are ever auspicious,
Those who follow the ghost Dao
Are ever inauspicious.
"Auspicious" means forsaking desire,
"Inauspicious" means clinging to desire.
Only the lofty and sagely,
Their words pure and numinous,
Pity the heavenly beings,
Who easily enter the ghostly realm,
Thus composing void hymns.
Recounting the suffering of the six desires,
They do not wish them to fall.
The Northern Capital’s Spring Bend
Is a place of confinement.
When heavenly beings exhaust their retribution,
They enter its bounds.
Hence: a myriad ghosts gather within,
Only seeking to cut short human years,
Sever the human gate of life.
The joy of desire’s stain
Brings such retribution.
Heavenly beings who preserve the human path,
Deeply abhor the ghostly realm,
Thus: Ah! Constantly sing the hymns of the Hollow Cavern,
Subduing demonic kinds,
Severing the roots of the six desires—hence, "blades."

Verse:
The six desires originally arise from darkness,
Dragging one into the ghostly path—how lamentable!
If you comprehend the sorrowful hymn’s meaning,
Bind all demonic hordes, and the Dao’s eye opens.

**Second: The Demon-King’s Chapter of the Form Realm**
The beings of this heaven delight in form and dust,
Thus the path of Jade Purity is expounded,
To leave form and forget dust,
Ascend the mysterious and enter the wondrous.
Lofty and vast,
Luminous qi spreads in four directions.
The Brahma-conduct, the balanced scales of sound—
The heavens encircle the ten directions.
Boundless great spirits
All arise from my body.
I possess the hymns of the Hollow Cavern,
Myriad transformations perfect immortals.
The immortal Dao values deliverance,
The ghost Dao clings to connection.
Heaven and earth are faint and vast,
Impure qi swirls thickly.
The joys of the three realms
Pass by, yet endure.
Deliver your body through my realm,
Your form enters spontaneity.
This joy
Is but slight grace from me.
The Dragon Han era flows boundlessly—
How can one distinguish the true?
My realm is difficult to deliver,
Thus I compose the hymns of the Hollow Cavern.
Transforming and flying through the void,
To test your body.
Success or failure, laxity or retreat—
How many are delivered?
Laughing at your failure to be delivered,
Thus I sing these hymns.

chunks.original_text: 此天落落然高张远大，明骞之炁四朗，乃梵炁所化，周布十方也。 无量大神，即天中魔试之所变，故云皆由我身。 盖仙道好度，出此洞章，使人了忘色尘，超出空有，升入三清。 而天人自以为乐，不知所向，故云仙道贵度。 而鬼道常与相连，所谓进则成仙，退则成鬼，进退之间，人当自择。 天地之间眇莽高大，秽气氛积，色界虽乐，尚有劫灾坠之下苦，失之不难。 须得了忘尘染，升入三境，乃可长存。 能度此界，则真相之体进入自然，当尔之时，不生不灭，万为乐也。 我恩，谓色尘； 良由超出色尘也。 龙汉，谓玉清上圣之道。 荡荡无际，皆可证之，今尔等但以色界为乐，故真伪莫分，故化洞章以相勉也。 千变万化，魔试天人，其间懈怠者多，升进者少。 笑尔不求自度，故作是言也。 颂曰： 人言此界极难度，我道色尘容易消。 但使自家心似铁，从教炉铸火来烧。 第三无色界魔王歌曰： 此界天人以遣心故，返为所累，故魔王述以匡御之道。 令识变诈，使决证神仙。 三界之上，眇眇天罗。 上无色根，云层峨峨。 唯有元始，浩劫之家。 部制我界，统承玄都。 有过我界，身入玉虚。 我位上王，匡御众魔。 空中万变，秽气纷葩。 保真者少，迷惑者多。 仙道难固，鬼道易邪。 人道者心，谅不由他。 仙道贵实，人道贵华。 尔不乐仙道，三界那得过。 其欲转五道，我当复奈何。 此界天人去色忘尘，而未达究竟之道，以遣魔故，返为魔累，故天王陈匡御之法，欲开悟之。 言此三界之上，惟有眇眇大罗无色之宗，但云层峨峨而已，下仙不可窥盻。 得元始之道居其中，无有终始，故云浩劫之家也。 统系玉京部制，过此分界，则转玉虚之境。 魔王自言我居此天最上王位，常匡御众魔，方保长存； 飞空之中，千变万化，升度学人，而尘秽之气常自纷葩也。 言天人虽则离染忘色，未能遣忘，尤以心识为患。 至於观空入妙，尤复为难。 故鬼道易为，邪入欲作，真人忘心，自遣而已。 谅不由於他事，乃为仙道者以实，为人道者以华。 今尔等天人若不进登真仙之道，则三界何以超凌。 颂曰： 声声劝我御群魔，惟是韦魔直恁多。 要做神仙元自已，若居鬼道不由他。 纪述功果一百一十七言。 前者以显戒言，则今明示所得决定功果，以坚固学人。 参校曰：此青元注经条分八事之终也。 此三界之上，飞空之中，魔王歌音，音参洞章。 诵之百徧，名度南官。 诵之千徧，魔王保迎。 万徧道备，飞升太空。 过度三界，位登仙公。 有闻灵音，魔王敬形。 敕制地祇，侍卫送迎。 拔出地户，五苦八难，七祖升迁，永离鬼官。 魂度朱陵，受炼更生，是谓无量，普度无穷。 如上歌音者，乃三界之上、飞空之中，魔王之所制也。 其音参大洞之章，若人诵之百徧，亦如天人，离尘绝欲，故得名度南宫。 诵之千徧，亦如天人观空入妙，是为道备，飞升太空。 仙公者，太极第一品之仙真。 此则诵经功德所获如是。 其有闻见者，次获如下功德：魔王敬形，敕制地只，侍卫送迎，拔出地户五苦八难，虽七祖皆得受生。 如是生死兼济，故云无量无穷。 有秘上天文，诸天共所崇。 泄慢堕地狱，祸及七祖翁。 此经尽天地万有、圣贤资生，皆所总言，故劫以四万之远方许传度，恐下士轻易，重设禁纲而为偈。

This celestial realm stretches vast and lofty, its luminous qi radiant in the four directions—transformed from the pure qi of Brahma, it pervades the ten directions. The boundless great spirits are but the illusory forms of heavenly demonic trials, hence it is said they all arise from my body. The Dao of immortals favors deliverance; through these Hollow Cavern hymns, one may forget the dust of form, transcend both emptiness and existence, and ascend into the Three Clarities. Yet heavenly beings mistake their joy for true bliss, unaware of their direction—thus it is said the immortal Dao values deliverance. The ghostly Dao ever clings to them, for advancement leads to immortality, while retreat leads to ghosthood; between progress and withdrawal, one must choose for oneself.

Between heaven and earth, the vastness is profound, impure qi thickly accumulates, and though the realm of form brings joy, it still harbors the suffering of kalpic disasters and falls—loss comes all too easily. One must forget the defilements of the dust, ascend into the Three Realms, and only then may one endure. To be delivered through this realm is to enter the true form of spontaneity; in that moment, neither birth nor extinction arises, and all becomes joy. My grace refers to the dust of form; it is precisely by transcending this dust that one attains it.

The Dragon Han is the Dao of the Jade Clarity’s supreme sages. Boundless and without limit, all may realize it, yet now you take joy only in the realm of form—thus truth and falsehood blur, and I compose these Hollow Cavern hymns to exhort you. Through myriad transformations, demons test heavenly beings; among them, the lax are many, the ascendant few. Laughing at your failure to seek self-deliverance, I speak these words.

**Hymn:**
Men say this realm is most difficult to cross,
I say the dust of form is easily dissolved.
If but your heart were iron,
Let the furnace’s fire forge and burn.

**The Third Formless Realm’s Demon King’s Song:**
The beings of this realm, through clinging to the mind, are instead ensnared by it—thus the Demon King expounds the way of correction, teaching them to recognize deception and decisively realize immortality.

Above the Three Realms, the vast Celestial Net stretches;
Above, no root of form, only cloud-layers towering.
Only the Primordial Beginning dwells
In the home of endless kalpas.
My realm is governed,
Inheriting the Mysterious Capital.
Those who transgress my realm
Enter the Jade Void.
I, the supreme king,
Correct and govern all demons.
In the void’s myriad transformations,
Impure qi blooms in profusion.
Those who preserve truth are few,
Those who stray and delude are many.
The immortal Dao is hard to stabilize,
The ghostly Dao easily turns to evil.
The human Dao lies in the heart—
Truly, it does not depend on others.
The immortal Dao values substance,
The human Dao values splendor.
If you do not delight in the immortal Dao,
How can you transcend the Three Realms?
Should you wish to cycle through the Five Paths,
What then can I do for you?

The beings of this realm, though they leave form and forget the dust, have not yet attained the ultimate Dao. Through clinging to demons, they are instead burdened by them—thus the Heavenly King sets forth the way of correction, seeking to awaken them. Above the Three Realms, only the vast Celestial Net of the formless origin remains, its cloud-layers towering, beyond the gaze of lesser immortals. Those who attain the Dao of the Primordial Beginning dwell within it, without beginning or end—hence it is called the home of endless kalpas. It is governed by the Jade Capital; beyond this boundary lies the realm of the Jade Void. The Demon King declares: I occupy the highest throne of this heaven, ever correcting and governing all demons to preserve enduring existence. In the flying void, with myriad transformations, I deliver those who cultivate, yet the impure qi of the dust ever blooms in profusion.

Though heavenly beings have left defilement and forgotten form, they have not yet relinquished their attachments, for the mind’s perceptions remain a hindrance. To contemplate emptiness and enter subtlety is yet more difficult. Thus the ghostly Dao is easily embraced, evil enters through desire, while true beings forget the mind through self-abandonment—truly, it does not depend on external matters. The immortal Dao values substance, the human Dao values splendor. If you, heavenly beings, do not advance toward the true immortal Dao, how then can you transcend the Three Realms?

**Hymn:**
Again and again I urge you to govern the demon hordes,
Yet still the demon hordes are so very many.
To become an immortal lies within yourself—
To dwell in the ghostly Dao does not depend on others.

**Record of Meritorious Fruits: One Hundred Seventeen Words**
The preceding has set forth admonitions; now the determined fruits of attainment are made clear to strengthen the resolve of cultivators.

**Collation:**
This concludes the eighth section of the *Qingyuan* commentary on the scripture.

Above the Three Realms, within the flying void, the Demon King’s songs interweave with the Hollow Cavern hymns. To recite them a hundred times is to be delivered through the Southern Palace. To recite them a thousand times is to have the Demon King safeguard and welcome you. After ten thousand recitations, the Dao is complete, and you ascend into the great void. Having transcended the Three Realms, you attain the rank of Immortal Duke. Those who hear these numinous sounds receive the following merits: the Demon King respects their form, commands earth spirits, and provides escort and welcome. They are extricated from the earthly prisons, the Five Sufferings and Eight Difficulties; even their seven generations of ancestors ascend, forever freed from the ghostly bureaus. Their souls cross the Vermilion Mound, undergo refinement, and are reborn—this is called boundless deliverance, universal salvation without end.

The above songs are composed by the Demon King above the Three Realms, within the flying void. Their verses interweave with the Great Hollow’s hymns. If one recites them a hundred times, like heavenly beings, one leaves the dust and severs desire—thus one is said to be delivered through the Southern Palace. To recite them a thousand times is to contemplate emptiness and enter subtlety like heavenly beings, the Dao thereby complete, ascending into the great void. The Immortal Duke is the first rank of immortals in the Supreme Ultimate. Such are the merits attained through the recitation of this scripture. Those who hear or witness it gain the following merits: the Demon King respects their form, commands earth spirits, provides escort and welcome, extricates them from the earthly prisons of the Five Sufferings and Eight Difficulties, and even their seven generations of ancestors are reborn. Thus both the living and the dead are saved—hence it is called boundless and infinite.

There are secret celestial texts,
Revered by all heavens.
To leak or slight them is to fall into hell,
Bringing calamity upon seven generations of ancestors.
This scripture encompasses all existence between heaven and earth, the sustenance of sages and worthies—thus, across forty thousand kalpas, its transmission is permitted only to the distant. Fearing that lesser beings might treat it lightly, strict prohibitions are set forth in verse.

Let later generations of shallow understanding take heed: those who recklessly alter or transmit to the unworthy should reflect upon these words.

chunks.original_text: 凡有此灾，同气皆当齐心修斋，六时行香，十徧转经，福德立降，消诸不祥。 无量之文，普度无穷。 未得真道之士否泰吉凶，故常理也。 后学心未坚固，乃设此章，以天地圣贤不逃大数，而况后学者乎！ 博达之士，三省斯言，自无魔试。 同气者，自清浊分。 一生二、二生三、三生万物，品物流形，均受元始一炁而生。 人人皆是同炁。 颂曰： 霄壤神人或异常，几夫安可没灾殃。 同心发个度人愿，十读斯文为解禳。 道言：夫末学道浅，或仙品未充，运应灭度，身经太阴。 临过之时，同学至人，为其行香诵经十过，以度尸形。 如法，魂神径上南宫，随其学功计日而得更生，转轮不灭，便得神仙。 末学之士，未遂成道，则仙曹未有名籍。 遇数则终，形识当坏，不免同入太阴； 返视阳仙，诚隔霄壤。 若同学之流为之济度，方得返形为阳。 颂曰： 学人修道冀登真，逐妄翻成坠苦因。 若也同侪垂济度，南丹即日炼魂神。 道言：夫天地运终，亦当修斋、行香诵经。 星宿错度，日月失昏，亦当修斋、行香诵经。 四时失度，阴阳不调，亦当修齐、行香诵经。 国主有灾，兵革四兴，亦当修斋、行香诵经。 疫毒流行，兆民死伤，亦当修斋、行香诵经。 师友命过，亦当修斋、行香诵经。 夫斋戒诵经，功德甚重，上消天灾，保镇帝王； 下禳毒害，以度兆民。 生死受赖，其福难胜，故曰无量，普度天人。 自利利他为第一行，太上设此一章，明此经非惟度己，虽天地君臣民庶皆可兼济，方为道备，乃显度人之普。 颂曰： 学人修习洞玄章，慈爱之心不可忘。 为国为家兼济度，度人功德始无量。 道言：凡有是经，能为天地帝主兆民行是功德，有灾之日，发心修齐，烧香诵经十过，皆诸天记名，万神侍卫，右别至人，克得为圣君金阙之臣。 诸天记人功过，毫分无失。 天中魔王亦保举尔身得道者，乃当洞明至言也。 宗奉礼敬，轻泄漏慢，有一至此，则鬼神所不容私，而况诸天乎！ 太上以世人之志成毁无定，故云诸天记人功过，毫分无失。 前章已是诵经威仪，今复以四种美功重伸优劝。 皆诸天记名者，随功纪籍。 万神侍卫者，灵宝众神也。 友别者，五帝以友别之，称为至人。 克得为圣君金阙之臣者，即为后圣金阙之侍臣也。 颂曰： 学人志念若浮沤，勤惰难为定性求。 若也洞明灵宝语，上清即日可遨游。 诸天中大梵隐语无量音 元始灵书上篇

Whenever such calamities arise, all of like qi must unite in heart to perform purification rites, offer incense in the six periods, and recite the scriptures ten times over—whereupon virtue and power descend at once, dispelling all inauspiciousness. The boundless scriptures universally deliver the limitless. For those who have not attained the true Dao, the alternation of fortune and misfortune is but the constant principle. Later learners, their hearts not yet steadfast, are thus given this chapter: even heaven and earth, the sages and the worthies, cannot escape the great reckoning—how much less the later learners! Those of broad understanding should thrice reflect upon these words, and they shall know no demonic trials.

Those of like qi are distinguished from the outset by purity and turbidity. From the One comes the Two, from the Two comes the Three, and from the Three come the ten thousand things; all forms and beings receive life from the primordial qi of the Origin. Every person shares this same qi.

The Hymn states:
Though divine beings of heaven and earth may differ in station,
How can the lesser escape disaster and woe?
With one heart, vow to deliver others—
Ten recitations of this text serve as exorcism and deliverance.

The Dao declares: When lesser learners of the Dao are shallow in cultivation, or their immortal rank not yet fulfilled, their allotted span comes to an end, and their bodies pass through the Great Yin. At the hour of their passing, fellow students and perfected beings offer incense and recite the scriptures ten times to deliver their corporeal form. If the rites are performed correctly, the hun-soul ascends directly to the Southern Palace, where, according to the merit of their cultivation, they are reborn after a set number of days. Escaping the wheel of rebirth, they attain immortality.

For lesser learners who have not yet fulfilled the Dao, their names are not yet recorded in the registers of the immortals. When their allotted span ends, form and consciousness dissolve, and they cannot avoid entering the Great Yin. Looking back upon the immortals of the yang realm, they are truly as distant as heaven and earth. Only if their fellow students extend deliverance may they return to yang as embodied beings.

The Hymn states:
Learners of the Dao aspire to ascend to truth,
Yet chasing delusion, they fall into the causes of suffering.
If their peers extend deliverance,
That very day, their hun-souls are refined in the Southern Elixir.

The Dao declares: When the revolutions of heaven and earth reach their end, purification rites must be performed, incense offered, and scriptures recited. When the constellations fall out of alignment and the sun and moon lose their proper times, purification rites must be performed, incense offered, and scriptures recited. When the four seasons lose their order and yin and yang fall out of harmony, purification rites must be performed, incense offered, and scriptures recited. When the sovereign faces calamity and warfare erupts on all sides, purification rites must be performed, incense offered, and scriptures recited. When pestilence spreads and the people suffer death and injury, purification rites must be performed, incense offered, and scriptures recited. When teachers and companions pass away, purification rites must be performed, incense offered, and scriptures recited.

The merit of purification rites and scripture recitation is most weighty: above, it dispels heavenly calamities and safeguards the emperor; below, it averts poison and harm, delivering the people. In life and death, all rely upon it—its blessings are beyond measure. Thus it is called boundless, universally delivering heaven and humanity.

To benefit oneself and others is the foremost practice. The Most High established this chapter to clarify that this scripture not only delivers oneself but may also universally aid heaven and earth, sovereign and subjects, the people—only then is the Dao complete, and the universality of deliverance made manifest.

The Hymn states:
Learners who cultivate the Mysterious Chapters
Must not forget the heart of compassion and love.
For nation and family, extend deliverance—
Only then does the merit of delivering others become boundless.

The Dao declares: Whoever possesses this scripture and performs these meritorious deeds for heaven and earth, the sovereign, and the people—when calamity arises, if they resolve in their hearts to perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite the scriptures ten times—all the heavens record their names, the ten thousand spirits attend and protect them, and those of superior attainment are destined to become ministers of the Golden Portals of the Sage Sovereign. The heavens record the merits and faults of people without the slightest error. Even the demon kings of heaven will advocate for those who attain the Dao, for they have thoroughly mastered these profound words.

Those who revere and honor this teaching, yet lightly transgress or profane it, even once—such persons are not tolerated by spirits and gods, much less the heavens! The Most High, seeing that the resolve of worldly people wavers and falters, thus declares that the heavens record the merits and faults of people without the slightest error.

The preceding chapter already established the solemnity of scripture recitation; now, the four kinds of noble deeds are reiterated to further encourage and exhort. "All the heavens record their names" means their merits are inscribed in the celestial registers. "The ten thousand spirits attend and protect them" refers to the divine hosts of the Numinous Treasure. "Those of superior attainment" are distinguished by the Five Emperors as "Perfected Beings." "Destined to become ministers of the Golden Portals of the Sage Sovereign" means they shall serve as attendants to the Sage Sovereign of the Golden Portals.

The Hymn states:
If the learner’s resolve is as fleeting as foam,
Diligence and indolence make steadfastness hard to attain.
But if one thoroughly masters the words of the Numinous Treasure,
That very day, they may roam the Upper Clarity.

The boundless sounds of the Great Brahma’s hidden language in the heavens,
The first chapter of the Numinous Writ of the Origin.

The Dao declares: The revolutions of heaven and earth, too, know decline and end; the sun, moon, and five planets, too, wax and wane; even the most sagely and divine, too, know rest and cessation; and the lesser learners, too, know sickness and harm.

chunks.original_text: 东方八天 广生高映，觉元洞虚。 应玄九真，化交肇图。 文灵运构，宗范玄都。 感变总括，威昭自成。 绿岑迁景，皇道含明。 天琳耀权，炁精育魂。 融罗负立，圆英隐昱。 期巨神包，洪纲告宁。 南方八天 章炎通泛，坚敷澄宗。 虚象玄华，龙阳舞穹。 微正霄艳，渊太凝冲。 元关三纽，太梵飞空。 隐觉隆益，天伦庆呈。 神户缠络，真元散精。 净握冥昭，回合升迁。 导骞宴云，灵应腾天。 西方八天 刚泽徽控，阴峻孤仪。 贯炁明素，宸洞开微。 周化幽应，澄虚帝台。 平遐揖虚，恢茂童池。 结飙临育，丽无散开。 阳通百六，沉芒隐阶。 幽廓冥默，真峰会灵。 坚丕顺道，告命骞林。 北方八天 龙安洞变，纯阳隐玄。 方本还炁，象伏高员。 神变慧化，解炼灵根。 赤精纯道，成号威尊。 利云友常，亿劫中丘。 郁城琼垒，谣音庆流。 受位玉室，大宪通幽。 玄章焕落，纲轮乃周。 上篇龙章凤篆之文，亦名除禳水火漂溺玉章。 参校曰：青元经注引《天公经》云：大罗官宫上篇。 观觉郁缢者，龙篆正文谓此也。 蜀本叔在灵书下篇后，但既曰上篇，章篆合置上篇之列。 别本已有置此在上篇后者，今从之。 观觉郁褴，太明紫灵。 九神度魂，开关玉真。 阿奕炜灿，飞天流音。 轮景帝常，都灵颐臻。 豁落大有，庆云启灵。 七曜辉魔，恬懀敷荣。 虚无上首，天启弥宸。 四吁育象，濯曜腾精。 焕赫洞阳，浮景玉光。 七灵谣歌，世元紫堂。 罗英散景，耀明玉房。 八景总兽，韶王摄精。 九都骞郁，飞生上灵。 密罗净境，馥郁空轮。 灌沃黄华，霐运玄明。 神官开朗，延宛丹庭。 大猷浮景，真定化元。 蜓宛素眇，玉梁澄烟。 萧峙结嵎，景罗七缠。 秀盘三府，流辉九玄。 寂然虚邈，飞华拂軿。 晨滥录籍，太漠由延。 阿丘九度，六龙舞辕。 蓊蔼浮罗，紫精馥渊。 溟涬太育，九机化乾。 覆形厚德，元河瀹精。 育英明陀，景辰眇云。 大陈总监，秀乐禁天。 紫虚陀丘，劫量交前。 碧霞韵梵，眇眇游元。 六变运量，馘绝恶愆。 恢寂玄漠，万度成仙。 元始灵书中篇　道君撰 《天公经》云：虽有诸天，犹拘劫运，於是玉宸道君撰《元始灵书》四篇，凝云作篆，每字方广一丈，八角垂芒，以镇三十二天。 大罗宫有上篇，观觉郁褴，龙篆正文。 中篇即此文也。 道君所述下篇，即森角储云，乃皇人美此隐音，重述之也。 东方八天 叩齿九通，思九色玄龙导引从前，后青云九重，覆匝身形。 密咒曰： 赤明开图，九炁回真。 总统元关，青帝大神。 流化九外，缠绵我身。 灵音八书，六十四篇。 洞明天地，与我合仙。 运政龙驾，上升帝轩。 呎毕，引炁九咽止。 亶娄阿苍，无想观音。 亶娄即玉京山上长楼也。 阿者，此天司候之神名。 阿那苍者，天中游冶台名。 无者，虚无； 和者，日月之户。 观者，观觉天帝之讳。 音者，歌音，谓玉京亶娄。 其势长大，上接玄都之阿； 每朝会时，阿那登此楼击大鼓，则诸天真圣皆集歌洞章，自日月户间，朝元始于虚无也。 然后天帝观觉、领真人登游冶之台，三唱洞章，以开度人天。 此则元始以镇黄曾天之云文。 须延明首，法揽菩昙。 须延，皆天真之讳。 明首，先圣之名。 法、揽、菩、昙即玉清四府真人也。 当大劫交，元始命须延开玉真之府，纳诸仙真。
chunks.translated_text:
The Eight Heavens of the East:
Vast and life-generating, they illumine the heights,
Awakening the primordial through the cavernous void.
Responding to the Mysterious Nine Perfected,
Their transformative intermingling initiates the cosmic pattern.
The literary numina weave their structures,
While the ancestral model resides in the Mysterious Capital.
All responsive changes are encompassed,
Their majestic radiance self-manifesting.
Verdant peaks shift their vistas,
The imperial Dao embraces luminosity.
Celestial jade shines with authority,
Qi-essence nurtures the hun-souls.
Fused in a net of radiance, they stand firm,
The circular brilliance concealed in hidden splendor.
Their appointed vast spirits envelop all,
The grand net proclaims tranquility.

The Eight Heavens of the South:
Vermilion flames diffuse and pervade,
Firmly unfolding to clarify the ancestral lineage.
The empty image of the Mysterious Flower,
The Dragon-Yang dances in the vault of heaven.
Subtle rectitude gleams in the clouds,
The profound and grand congeal in stillness.
The primordial pass has three junctures,
The Great Brahma soars through the void.
Hidden awakening brings abundant benefit,
The celestial order presents its felicity.
Divine portals entwine in networks,
True primordiality scatters its essence.
Pure grasp of the obscure and luminous,
Revolving and uniting, they ascend and transmigrate.
Guiding the soaring, they feast upon clouds,
Spiritual responses ascend to heaven.

The Eight Heavens of the West:
Firm and lustrous, they subtly govern,
Yin’s austere solitary majesty.
Piercing qi clarifies the plain,
The imperial cavern opens the subtle.
Encompassing transformations respond in obscurity,
The clarified void is the Emperor’s terrace.
Pacifying the distant, they bow to the void,
Expanding the lushness of the Youthful Pool.
Binding whirlwinds descend to nurture,
Their beauty unscattered and unfurled.
Yang penetrates the hundred and six,
Submerged radiance conceals the steps.
The obscure expanse is profoundly silent,
True peaks convene the numinous.
Firm and grand, they follow the Dao,
Proclaiming their mandate to the soaring groves.

The Eight Heavens of the North:
Dragon-Peace transforms through the cavernous,
Pure Yang concealed in the Mysterious.
The square root returns to qi,
The image lies hidden in the lofty round.
Spiritual transformations and wise transformations,
Unbinding and refining the numinous root.
Crimson essence, pure Dao,
Their established title is Majestic and Honored.
Beneficial clouds are ever constant,
Through kalpas, they abide in the central mounds.
Lush cities of jade ramparts,
Their odes and melodies flow with felicity.
Receiving positions in the Jade Chamber,
The great statutes penetrate the obscure.
Mysterious chapters blaze and scatter,
The net’s wheel thus completes its cycle.

The Dragon Script and Phoenix Seal of the Upper Chapter,
Also named the Jade Chapters for Dispelling Calamities of Water and Fire.
Collated and noted: The *Qingyuan Jing Zhu* cites the *Heavenly Duke Scripture*,
Stating: "The Upper Chapter of the Great Luo Palace."
The "Observing Awareness, Luxuriant and Rich" refers to the Dragon Seal’s orthodox text.
The Shu edition places it after the Lower Chapter,
But since it is called the Upper Chapter, its seal script should be placed in the Upper Chapter’s sequence.
Other editions have already placed this after the Upper Chapter; we follow this arrangement.

Observing Awareness, Luxuriant and Rich,
The Great Luminance and Purple Numinosity.
The Nine Spirits deliver souls,
Opening the passes to the Jade Perfected.
Ah-Yi, resplendent and dazzling,
Flying heavens stream with sound.
The Wheel of Light, the Emperor’s constancy,
The Capital of Numinosity attains fulfillment.
Vast and open, the Great Possession,
Felicitous clouds initiate the numinous.
The Seven Luminaries radiate demons,
Serene and harmonious, they unfold glory.
The Void’s supreme origin,
Heaven’s revelation extends to the imperial abode.
The Four Exhalations nurture images,
Washing and shining, they soar with essence.
Brilliant and resplendent, penetrating Yang,
Floating vistas of jade light.
The Seven Numinous sing their odes,
The Purple Hall of the World’s Origin.
Net heroes scatter their vistas,
Illuminating the Jade Chambers.
The Eight Vistas gather their beasts,
The Shao King captures essence.
The Nine Capitals soar in luxuriance,
Flying life ascends to the Upper Numinous.
The Secret Net’s pure realm,
Fragrant and lush, the empty wheel.
Irrigating and nourishing the Yellow Flower,
The vast movement of the Mysterious Luminance.
Divine officials open and brighten,
Extending and winding through the cinnabar courts.
The great plan floats in light,
True constancy transforms the origin.
Graceful and subtle, white and distant,
The jade beams clarify the mist.
Pines stand in towering seclusion,
Vistas entwine in sevenfold coils.
Elegance coils through the Three Palaces,
Flowing radiance through the Nine Mysteries.
Silent and distant, the void remote,
Flying blossoms brush the imperial carriage.
Morning overflows the registers,
The Great Desert extends its course.
Ah-Qiu’s nine crossings,
Six dragons dance their traces.
Lush and misty, floating nets,
Purple essence, fragrant and profound.
The primordial vastness nurtures greatly,
The nine mechanisms transform Qian.
Covering forms with profound virtue,
The primordial river bathes essence.
Nurturing heroes, illuminating the distant,
Vistas of dawn, distant clouds.
The great array oversees all,
Elegant music restrains heaven.
The Purple Void’s distant mounds,
Kalpas’ measures intersect before them.
Azure clouds resonate with Brahma,
Distant and distant, roaming the origin.
Six transformations revolve their measures,
Severing and absolving evil transgressions.
Expansive stillness, the Mysterious Desert,
Ten thousand crossings achieve immortality.

The Middle Chapter of the *Numinous Writ of the Origin*,
Composed by the Dao Lord.

The *Heavenly Duke Scripture* states: Though there are many heavens, they are still bound by kalpic revolutions. Thereupon, the Jade Imperial Dao Lord composed the four chapters of the *Numinous Writ of the Origin*, congealing clouds into seal script. Each character was a square zhang in breadth, with eight corners trailing radiance, to pacify the thirty-two heavens. The Great Luo Palace holds the Upper Chapter—"Observing Awareness, Luxuriant and Rich"—the Dragon Seal’s orthodox text. The Middle Chapter is this text. The Lower Chapter, composed by the Dao Lord, is the "Forest of Horns Storing Clouds," wherein the August Person praises this hidden sound and expounds it anew.

The Eight Heavens of the East:
Knock the teeth nine times, visualize the nine-colored Mysterious Dragon leading the way ahead, with nine layers of blue clouds behind, enveloping the body’s form.

The secret incantation states:
Vermilion clarity opens the pattern,
Nine qi return to the true.
Governing the primordial pass,
The Great Spirit of the Blue Emperor.
Flowing transformations beyond the nine,
Entwining around my body.
Numinous sounds of eight writings,
Sixty-four chapters.
Penetrating heaven and earth,
Uniting with me as immortal.
Driving the dragon carriage,
Ascending to the imperial chariot.

After reciting, guide the qi and swallow nine times, then cease.

Danlou Acang,
The Contemplation of No-Thought Avalokiteśvara.
Danlou is the long tower atop Jade Capital Mountain.
Ah is the name of the celestial inspector of this heaven.
Anacang is the name of the roaming terrace in heaven.
Wu means emptiness; he means the gate of sun and moon.
Guan means observing, the taboo name of the Heavenly Emperor.
Yin means song, referring to the Jade Capital Danlou.
Its form is vast and great, reaching upward to the Alaya of the Mysterious Capital.
At each court assembly, Anacang ascends this tower to strike the great drum, whereupon all the celestial perfected and sages gather to sing the cavernous chapters. From between the gates of sun and moon, they pay homage to the Originator in the void. Then the Heavenly Emperor Guan Jue, leading the perfected, ascends the roaming terrace, thrice singing the cavernous chapters to open the deliverance of humans and heavens. This is the cloud script by which the Originator pacifies the Yellow Layered Heaven.

Xu Yan, Ming Shou,
Fa Lan, Pu Tan.
Xu Yan are the taboo names of the celestial perfected.
Ming Shou is the name of a former sage.
Fa, Lan, Pu, and Tan are the four perfected of the Jade Clarity’s four palaces.
When the great kalpa turns, the Originator commands Xu Yan to open the Jade Perfected’s palace to receive the many immortals.

The Hymn states:
If the learner’s resolve is as fleeting as foam,
Diligence and indolence make steadfastness hard to attain.
But if one thoroughly masters the words of the Numinous Treasure,
That very day, they may roam the Upper Clarity.

The boundless sounds of the Great Brahma’s hidden language in the heavens,
The first chapter of the Numinous Writ of the Origin.
